There was no fire.<ref name="google10">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eM0_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=ClgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1194,4831381&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Youngstown Vindicator - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1952 On July 9, a gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned near [[York, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="google11">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1913&dat=19520709&id=VfVGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4fMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3938,623061|title=Lewiston Evening Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1952 A pipeline explosion killed 2 men near [[Ackerly, Texas]] on July 17. * 1952 Four men working on an 8-inch gas pipeline near [[Mount Pleasant, Michigan]] were burned when that pipeline ruptured as they raised it for reconditioning on September 26.<ref name="google12">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VzkiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D6wFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5108,3178307&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Owosso Argus-Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1952 On October 18, a 26-inch gas pipeline, a branch of the "[[Big Inch]]" pipeline, started leaking at an insulated flange in [[Liberty Corner, New Jersey]]. A road was closed during the leak.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1952/10/19/92673113.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=GAS INVADES LIFE AT LIBERTY CORNER; But Folk of Old Jersey Village Wait Calmly for Mending of Break in Pipeline | date=October 19, 1952}}</ref> * 1952 On December 29, twelve persons were injured in a blast that shook the Lawndale district of [[Los Angeles, California]], when a ditching machine broke a gasoline-carrying pipeline and touched off a fiery explosion.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/424944471.html?dids=424944471:424944471&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Dec+30%2C+1952&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=12+Injured+in+Explosion+of+Gasoline&pqatl=google | title=12 Injured in Explosion of Gasoline | date=December 30, 1952}}</ref> * 1953 Five square miles of east of [[Boston, Massachusetts]] was evacuated on September 9 from a pipeline leaking about {{convert|1,000,000|USgal|L}} of gasoline.<ref name="google13">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9mEpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VIEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5457,1189575&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Schenectady Gazette - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1953 On September 10, a gas explosion in [[Cleveland, Ohio]] killed one person and injured 50 others.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1686706612.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+11%2C+1953&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=Cleveland+Gas+Blast+Kills+Woman%2C+Injures+50+Persons&pqatl=google | title=Cleveland Gas Blast Kills Woman, Injures 50 Persons | date=September 11, 1953 | work=The Sun}}</ref> * 1953 A 30-inch gas transmission pipeline exploded on October 18 near [[Uniontown, Pennsylvania]], causing a massive fire that burned 5 miles of cornfields. There were no injuries reported.<ref name="google14">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YB5aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cksNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5138,1480118&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1953 A US Air Force T-33 trainer jet crashed into a natural gas pipeline bridge over the [[Mississippi River]] on November 24 near [[Greenville, Mississippi]], rupturing and igniting the pipeline.<ref name="google15">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iIpWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z0ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=4630,3488063&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1954 On January 17, a [[Panhandle Eastern]] gas transmission pipeline exploded in [[Lucas County, Ohio]], causing some nearby residents to evacuate. a crater 60 feet long, 10 feet deep, and 8 feet wide. Two other explosion had occurred on this pipeline in the previous 2 years in Lucas County, but a Panhandle Eastern representative said the 3 explosions were just a coincidence.<ref name="google16">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19540118&id=FEdOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fgAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3392,1086191|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1954 A 40- to 50-year-old LP gas distribution line was blamed for causing an explosion in [[Goldsboro, North Carolina]] on April 12 that killed 5 people, injured 15 others, and demolished 3 buildings.<ref name="google17">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KlBgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W3ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=6706,589983&dq=propane+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Star-News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 On February 15, a 20-inch Cities Service pipeline exploded south of [[Lawrence, Kansas]], ejecting a 20-foot section of pipeline. There was no fire or injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19550216&id=mdlFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=w-cMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4053,2749402|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> * 1955 The "[[Big Inch]]" gas pipeline exploded and burned near [[Roseville, Ohio]] on March 7. Flames reached {{convert|400|ft|m}} high, and {{convert|8|acre|m2}} of brush & timber burned.<ref name="google18">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7hdUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tzkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4781,2989734&dq=big+inch+pipeline&hl=en|title=St. Joseph News-Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 On March 9, a pipeline construction crew of 4 were killed while trying to move a pipeline for the building of a Toll road in [[Chesterton, Indiana]]. Two other pipeline workers were injured, and a school a quarter mile away was evacuated.<ref name="google19">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7xdUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tzkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4747,3085315&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=St. Joseph News-Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 A burst pipeline at a Refinery in [[Sunburst, Montana]] contaminated groundwater and soil in the area. Despite pumping out over {{convert|182,000|USgal|L}} of gasoline, pollution from the accident remained. In 2004, local residents and a school district won a Lawsuit for payments for damages.<ref name="greatfallstribune">{{cite web|url=http://www.greatfallstribune.com/news/stories/20040819/localnews/1075244.html|title=Texaco must pay Sunburst $41M - greatfallstribune.com|publisher=greatfallstribune.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="toxipedia">{{cite web|url=http://toxipedia.org/display/toxipedia/Sunburst%27s+Texaco+refinery|title=Sunburst's Texaco refinery - Toxipedia|publisher=toxipedia.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 A bulldozer ruptured and ignited a gas pipeline in [[Brookshire, Texas]]. Flames reached {{convert|250|ft|m}}, and the bulldozer operator was killed.<ref name="google20">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PNUzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IOsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5938,1185243&dq=ruptured+pipeline&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 On August 10, a gas leak in [[Ashtabula, Ohio]] was ignited by electrical equipment or lightning, causing a restaurant to explode. 21 people were killed, 15 more were injured, and 6 buildings destroyed.<ref name="google21">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5y1kAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5XsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6842,1721328&dq=gas+main+fire&hl=en|title=The Calgary Herald - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 A gas pipeline being tested in [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]] exploded and burned on September 7, injuring one person, and destroying 50 cars.<ref name="google22">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CaVHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sv4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1072,825942&dq=gas+main+fire&hl=en|title=Meriden Record - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 On October 10, a crew cleaning the outside of a natural gas pipeline with a heavy rubber ball ruptured a coupler, causing an explosion and fire east of [[Orleans, Indiana]]. Two members of the crew were killed, and 3 others were injured.<ref name="google23">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=N-IrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D2YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3953,736357&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Kentucky New Era - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1955 A drag line operation in a gravel pit in [[Irving, Texas]] ruptured an 8-inch diameter gasoline pipeline on November 30. Gasoline spread out over about {{convert|10|acre|m2}}, then exploded and burned. 1 home was destroyed, but the family living there was away at the time of the explosion.<ref name="google24">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uSBYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sPYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7216,6007452&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1956 On February 11, a corroded gas line from a gas main leaked, causing an explosion that killed 3 people at a meat packing plant in [[Toledo, Ohio]].<ref name="google25">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=G_MeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1U0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5271,3726082&dq=gas+main+fire&hl=en|title=The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1956 A trench digging machine being used in building a freeway cut into a gasoline pipeline in [[West Los Angeles, California]] on February 27. At least 3 people were burned, with 9 homes, a warehouse, and a laundry catching on fire.<ref name="google26">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JOE0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=_YcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3705,5750752&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1956 On April 26, a new 26 inch gas transmission was being pressure tested near [[Moab, Utah]] with gas exploded, then burned, causing damage to a utility pole, and damaging a half mile of the pipeline. Mines in the region were shut down due to the lack of power. There were no injuries.<ref name="google27">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19560421&id=EvtXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xfYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5677,2859128|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1956 A butane pipeline ruptured on October 16, forcing 25 families to evacuate from flammable fumes near [[Greenwich, Ohio]]. Trains were also stopped in the area, until the fumes dissipated. There were no injuries.<ref name="google28">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HKIyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FOwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6614,5236&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 On January 16, an explosion and fire occurred at a natural gas compressor station in [[Liberal, Kansas]], killing 3 workers at that station. 11 other workers were injured, and the fire burned for 2 hours. The shut down of this gas pipeline from the explosion affected customers as far away as Ohio in sub-zero weather conditions.<ref name="google29">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GAJGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yc8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=5583,2958581&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Portsmouth Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google30">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ayhcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bVUNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2188,531629&dq=pipeline+explosion+g:locus&hl=en|title=Youngstown Vindicator - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 Two explosion from a natural gas main killed 3 people in [[Peoria, Illinois]] on January 17. 7 others were injured, and a home and a 2-story building were leveled.<ref name="google31">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eawpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5vYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2471,3738111&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 On January 23, the "[[Little Inch]]" gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned near [[York, Pennsylvania]], causing flames reaching 200 feet high. There were no injuries.<ref name="google32">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fawpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5vYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5792,4876970&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 A leaking gas main in [[Reno, Nevada]] led to three explosions on February 6. 2 people were killed, 42 others injured, and 5 buildings were destroyed.<ref name="google33">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aX5HAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MXwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4086,3548933&dq=gas+main+fire&hl=en|title=Warsaw Times - Union - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 On June 3, a 26-inch natural gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned near [[Ellinwood, Kansas]], destroying a farm house. One person was injured.<ref name="google34">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jv5XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9_YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7140,222686&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 On October 18, a 16-inch gas transmission pipeline burst 30 miles from [[Spokane, Washington]], shutting down gas delivery to the Spokane area. A family near the rupture had to take cover.<ref name="google35">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QapfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jzIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2821,5990257&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Lewiston Morning Tribune - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1957 On December 5, a gas line in the basement of a store that was being worked on in [[Villa Rica, Georgia]], exploded. 13 people were killed in the explosion and following fire. At least 6 stores were destroyed.<ref name="google36">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LTJaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QEwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2954,4453700&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=St. Joseph Gazette - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1958 A natural gas metering station in [[Kimberly, Idaho]] exploded on February 17, killing two pipeline company workers, injuring another worker, and destroyed the metering building. There was no fire.<ref name="google37">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8_lTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2jgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=784,634871&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Sunday News-Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google38">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VolWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JucDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5461,5588353&dq=pipeline+explosion+g:locus&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1958 On June 1, gas leaking from a pipeline near [[Big Spring, Texas]] was ignited and exploded, killing 3 fishermen and seriously burning another fisherman.<ref name="google39">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JQIdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4YoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3902,62384&dq=killed+when+he+struck+a+pipeline&hl=en|title=Sarasota Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1958 A truck missed a curve on a road and crashed into a gas transmission pipeline compressor station near [[Kings Mountain, North Carolina]] on September 16. There was an explosion and fire, and the 2 men in the truck were killed.<ref name="google40">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TV1gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wXENAAAAIBAJ&pg=5200,2714152&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Star-News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1958 On October 4, a gasoline pipeline was ruptured by a bulldozer in [[Hobbs, New Mexico]]. The gasoline ignited, injuring 3 people, damaging 6 homes, and threatened a number of other homes for a time.<ref name="google41">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kPRVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cuIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3846,647380&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Eugene Register-Guard - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google42">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QPsnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5Q8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2674,3144088&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Sentinel - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1958 On November 9, a jet fuel pipeline ruptured near the [[Blue Creek (Idaho)|Blue Creek]] in Idaho. Fuel flowed down the creek, and later ignited, damaging one home and destroying 6 bridges. Several were sicked by the fumes from incident.<ref name="google43">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CDFWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=teYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7170,3675418&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google44">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aEBYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=B_cDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7216,2207583&dq=pipeline+explosion+g:locus&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1958 A leaking and burning gas line under a street lead to several explosions at a Hotel in [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]], on December 14. 7 people were killed and 23 others injured.<ref name="google45">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MDEaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uyUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5669,2658429&dq=sun+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1959 On April 29, a 20-inch pipeline owned by Laurel Pipeline ruptured near [[Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania]] spilling thousands of gallons of gasoline onto fields a streams. Earthen dams were built to reduce the amount of gasoline spilling into fishing streams. The pipeline had been recently built.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19590429&id=6zoyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7uQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6849,2123134|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> * 1959 On May 22, a [[Buckeye Partners]] oil pipeline ruptured in [[Sylvania, Ohio]], spouting up in the lawn of one homeowner.<ref name="google46">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19590522&id=8vITAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9AAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3164,852915|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1959 A worker on gas transmission pipeline was closing a valve, when it exploded near [[Newton, Pennsylvania]] on September 25. The worker was killed, and another worker was injured.<ref name="google47">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YwIqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kSYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5410,2177289&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1959 On October 8, a 10-inch propane pipeline burst in [[Austin, Texas]]. 400 families had to be evacuated, due to the explosion & fire hazard. Eventually, the fumes dissipated without incident. The rupture was caused by a weak section of pipe.<ref name="google48">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l4piAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rXcNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1049,3659911&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Washington Reporter - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref>
==1960s==
* 1960 Transwestern Pipeline Co.'s gas line 58 miles northwest of Roswell N.M. suffered an 8.1 mile brittle fracture during testing of the 30-inch X56 pipeline. It failed at about 850 psi.<ref> Oil & Gas Journal April 25, 1960 - Vol 58 No. 17</ref> * 1960 An estimated 125,000 persons in southwest Missouri were without gas in subfreezing temperatures for several days due to a ditch-digging machine rupturing a pipeline.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1701383552.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jan+22%2C+1960&author=&pub=The+Sun+%281837-1985%29&desc=125%2C000+LEFT+WITHOUT+FUEL+IN+MISSOURI&pqatl=google | title=125,000 Left Without Fuel In Missouri | date=January 22, 1960 | work=The Sun}}</ref> * 1960 On Saturday, March 19, a leaking 1 1/2 inch gas line lead to gas migrating through a sewer line, from a church into a school, in [[Wauseon, Ohio]]. The gas later exploded, damaging the school and injuring six. Classes were not in session at that time.<ref name="google49">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19600322&id=F2ZRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-gAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7141,6255426|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1960 In July, excavation work in [[Merrill, Wisconsin]] causes a gas leak and gas explosion that killed 10 people.<ref name="google50">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KTcaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9xAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5167,828174&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Sentinel - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1960 A ditching machine used in laying a water main hit an 8-inch natural gas pipeline in [[Sarasota, Florida]] on October 5. 9 People were injured in the following explosion and fire.<ref name="google51">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FXkcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KmUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7380,1060319&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Sarasota Herald-Tribune - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1960 On October 27, a 16-inch gas transmission pipeline near [[Checotah, Oklahoma]] exploded while it was being worked on to repair a leak. 2 of the repair crew died, and 4 others were injured.<ref name="google52">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=v29DAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JK4MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1347,1621086&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Altus Times-Democrat - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1960 On December 12, a leaking 8-inch pipeline at a tanker dock in [[Richmond, California]] spilled gasoline into the [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/12/13/99902161.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=FIRE PERIL IN COAST BAY; Gasoline From Pipeline Break Surrounds Two Vessels | date=December 13, 1960}}</ref> * 1960 A 30-inch gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned at a gas sub station in [[Huntington, West Virginia]] on December 19. Windows were broken, 1 home was damaged, and brush burned, but there were no injuries.<ref name="google53">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YNddAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6V4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4428,776370&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Washington Reporter - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1961 On January 4, a gas pipeline failure near [[Waynesburg, Pennsylvania]] ignited, causing a fire that was widely seen in the area. There were no injuries.<ref name="google54">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EsRWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=40ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=5975,1153855&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The News-Dispatch - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1961 On February 22, a pipeline exploded and burned in a refinery in [[Borger, Texas]], killing 9 members of a construction crew, and burning another crewman.<ref name="google55">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kWQtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lYkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2367,3226209&dq=phillips+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Schenectady Gazette - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1961 The main City of [[Miami, Florida]] Garage was destroyed by a gas explosion on February 23. The blast was caused by a ditch digging machine being used in the garage hitting and rupturing a 2-inch gas pipe. One person was seriously burned by the blast, and 2 fire fighters were injured fighting the fire that followed the blast.<ref name="google56">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AWlVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wD4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3738,4005810&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1961 A [[Transcontinental Pipeline]] 36-inch gas transmission pipeline exploded near [[Laurel, Mississippi]] on June 18. 10 people were injured, and one home was destroyed from flames that went hundreds of feet in the air. A crater {{convert|30|ft|m}} long and {{convert|20|ft|m}} deep was created by the failure.<ref name="google57">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Oj5QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IFcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2604,2966218&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Evening Independent - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1961/06/19/97674168.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=Ten Hurt in Pipeline Blast | date=June 19, 1961}}</ref> * 1961 A 26-inch gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned near [[Trapp, Kentucky]] on September 10. 22 people suffered various burn injuries.<ref name="google58">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8WpVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2z4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3645,5039444&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="centralkynews">{{cite web|url=http://articles.centralkynews.com/2011-09-14/winchestersun/30157958_1_gas-line-explosion-vaughn-burns|title=Gas line explosion injured 22 in Trapp 50 years ago - Central Kentucky News|publisher=articles.centralkynews.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="lex18">{{cite web|url=http://www.lex18.com/news/woman-reflects-on-pipeline-explosion-from-50-years-ago|title=Woman Reflects On Pipeline Explosion From 50 Years Ago | LEX18.com|publisher=lex18.com|accessdate=18 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223142840/http://www.lex18.com/news/woman-reflects-on-pipeline-explosion-from-50-years-ago|archivedate=23 February 2014|df=}}</ref> * 1961 On October 9, vapors from a leaking pipeline on an oil storage tank exploded and burned in [[Bridgeport, Illinois]]. 4 oil company workers were killed, and 3 others injured.<ref name="google59">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cUYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pk4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7319,4004006&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1961 On November 19, a gas pipeline exploded and burned near [[Warrenton, Virginia]]. The blast created a crater {{convert|40|ft|m}} long, {{convert|10|ft|m}} wide, and {{convert|6|ft|m}} deep. There were no injuries.<ref name="google60">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yQJdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BVoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3543,2844843&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=St. Joseph Gazette - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1961 An 18-inch natural gas pipeline exploded and burned near [[Cadiz, Ohio]] on November 25. There were no injuries or damage.<ref name="google61">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mUYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sE4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7267,3005942&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 Gas leaking from a 10-inch natural gas transmission pipeline exploded on February 20 in [[Portage, Ohio]], injuring 6 people and destroying a home.<ref name="google62">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-gFPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LQEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5401,1393923&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 On April 24, An earth mover hit a 10-inch [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline in [[Sylvania, Ohio]], causing a geyser of naphtha, which flowed into the [[Tenmile Creek (Ottawa River)|Ten Mile Creek]]. Nearby schools were impacted.<ref name="google63">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19620424&id=ygwwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LwEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6139,2249555|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 On June 14, a backhoe ruptured a gas transmission pipeline near [[Idaho Falls, Idaho]]. The escaping gas exploded and ignited later on while a crew was trying to repair the line. One of the crew was killed, and 5 others injured in the fire.<ref name="google64">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ieQuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C0oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3816,3304230&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Deseret News Salt Lake Telegram - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 On August 2, a natural gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned in [[Clearwater, Florida]], next to US Highway 19, forcing that road's closure for a time. There were no injuries reported. Investigators found the line had previous mechanical damage as a cause of the failure.<ref name="google65">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VQcTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EgUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1611,292896&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Ocala Star-Banner - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google66">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nXpPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fFIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6901,1637801&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=St. Petersburg Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 A 30-inch gas transmission failed on August 3 in [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. The gas flowed for 10 minutes before exploding and igniting. An 8-inch gas distribution pipeline was also ruptured, 11 homes were destroyed, and 23 others were damaged. At least one person was injured.<ref name="google67">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FD4yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=W-UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6099,2495364&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 On September 11, an 8-inch propane/LPG pipeline was ruptured by road building equipment near [[Eatonton, Georgia]]. One of the road workers was overcome and asphyxiated by the propane fumes. Propane fumes followed the [[Oconee River]] for {{convert|10|mi|km}} into Lake Sinclair.<ref name="google68">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tetMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZDEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6958,1257654&dq=propane+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Rome News-Tribune - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1962 On October 17, a gas main in [[Kansas City, Missouri]] exploded and burned, with flames 100 feet high, causing serious damage to one home, and minor damage to others. There were no injuries.<ref name="google69">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1913&dat=19621017&id=r74gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yWkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1675,4473894|title=Lewiston Evening Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 On January 2, a gas transmission pipeline ruptured, due to a defective weld, in [[San Francisco, California]]. The gas ignited, one firefighter died from a heart attack, and 9 other firefighters were injured fighting the resulting inferno.<ref name="mercurynews">{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/san-bruno-fire/ci_18351330|title=Documents show history of flawed welds on gas pipe next to San Bruno line - San Jose Mercury News|publisher=mercurynews.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google70">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=u8leAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZTIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2228,234282&dq=san+francisco+fire&hl=en|title=Lewiston Morning Tribune - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 On January 10, a pipeline spilled gasoline across US 27 in [[Coldwater, Michigan]]. There were no injuries or ignition.<ref name="google71">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1978&dat=19630109&id=0WkiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PKsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4430,662659|title=The Owosso Argus-Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 A leaking gas main led to an explosion in 3 homes that killed a man and injured several more in [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania]] on January 26.<ref name="lehighvalleylive">{{cite web|url=http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/entertainment-general/index.ssf/2013/01/a_gas_explosion_killed_a_bethl.html|title=A gas explosion killed a Bethlehem man in 1963 - Almanac Jan. 26, 2013|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=lehighvalleylive.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 An explosion and fire spread through a gas pipeline compressor station in [[Montezuma, Indiana]] on March 12, injuring 16 workers.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/948457832.html?dids=948457832:948457832&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+13%2C+1963&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=16+Hurt+In+Plant+Explosion&pqatl=google | work=The Hartford Courant | title=16 Hurt In Plant Explosion | date=March 13, 1963}}</ref> * 1963 On September 18, crews installing a 12-inch pipeline hit an 8-inch [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline in [[Monroe, Michigan]], releasing some petroleum product. Traffic in that area was snarled, and several homes nearby were voluntarily evacuated.<ref name="google72">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19630918&id=RrFOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PQEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3428,1582024|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 A crude oil pipeline was hit and ruptured by an earth mover near [[Fostoria, Ohio]], on October 30. The earth mover operator was seriously burned in the resulting fire.<ref name="google73">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HmZRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jgEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4892,2026043&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 On October 31, a 6-inch butane pipeline was ruptured by an earth mover near [[West Millgrove, Ohio]]. The equipment operator was critically burned by the following explosion and fire.<ref name="google74">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H2ZRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jgEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4487,2297712&dq=sun+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1963 On November 17, flammable liquids leaking from a pipeline disposal pit were accidentally ignited, killing a teen planning to cook alongside a creek in South Carolina.<ref name="google75">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3UksAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rc4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4698,2938515&dq=colonial+pipeline&hl=en|title=Herald-Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 A [[Santa Fe Railroad]] Freight Train apparently ignited fumes from a leaking propane pipeline near [[Bosworth, Missouri]] on February 4. The explosion and fire ignited 4 diesel locomotives and some box cars, and derailed other box cars. One member of the Rail Crew was injured.<ref name="google76">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kgVdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EFoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3818,1891839&dq=mid+american+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=St. Joseph Gazette - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 On February 7, 2 workers installing insulation on a valve in a manhole in [[Richardson, Texas]] were overcome by gas when an 8-inch pipeline in the vault ruptured, and were killed.<ref name="google77">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-TdSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WDYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5015,4305460&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 A front loader ruptured a gas pipeline in [[Fort Worth, Texas]] on February 28, seriously burning the loader operator.<ref name="google78">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ADhSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WDYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1529,132915&dq=propane+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 On May 12, a bulldozer hit and broke a valve on an LPG pipeline near [[Demopolis, Alabama]] while grading land. The resulting fire caused fears of flames spreading to an underground storage facility, but the fire was later controlled. There were no injuries.<ref name="google79">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LfscAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BZsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5508,1782323&dq=dixie+pipeline&hl=en|title=The Tuscaloosa News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 On August 22, crews working on an extension of [[Plantation Pipeline]] in [[Ferry Farms, Virginia]] hit a natural gas pipeline. Gas escaped for over 3 hours before it was shut off.<ref name="google80">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19640824&id=895NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8YoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4061,5016163|title=The Free Lance-Star - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 On September 1, a 24-inch natural gas transmission pipeline being worked on exploded near [[Pratt, Kansas]], burning 9 of the crew.<ref name="hutchnews">{{cite web|url=http://www.hutchnews.com/news/local_state_news/ghost-acres-affect-payments-for-crop-disaster/article_d96edf79-8f5c-5570-b3a0-6a1c04b662f4.html|title=‘Ghost acres’ affect payments for 1989 crop disaster - The Hutchinson News: Local/State News|publisher=hutchnews.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 A crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Gilbertown, Alabama]] on October 29. More than {{convert|72,000|USgal|L}} of oil were spilled.<ref name="google81">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LwQpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QNUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2034,2806701&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Gadsden Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 A gas line being moved in [[Miami, Florida]] exploded and burned on November 18. 4 people were injured.<ref name="google82">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZKYyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NOkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2135,904257&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1964 On November 25, a recently replace natural gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned in [[Saint Francisville, Louisiana]], killing 5 workers of the pipeline, and injuring at least 23 others.<ref name="google83">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Q1odAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AFkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5523,7766296&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 On January 6, a house in [[Garnett, Kansas]] was destroyed by an explosion, and later on gas was found leaking from a 2-inch gas line in the street front of it, and was suspected as the cause. A young boy was killed. The leak may have also caused another nearby house explosion the previous November.<ref name="google84">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RwNUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DTkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4092,706099&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 On January 21, an 8-inch [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline propane transmission pipeline {{convert|15|mi|km}} east of [[Jefferson City, Missouri]] leaked. The propane spread along the ground, and exploded several hours later, scorching an area over a mile wide. A girl being dropped off at a school bus stop was severely burned and later died, and 2 other people were burned.<ref name="google85">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=20IrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XNQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2031,850342&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Nevada Daily Mail - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 A 32-inch gas transmission pipeline, north of [[Natchitoches, Louisiana]], belonging to the [[Tennessee Gas Pipeline]] exploded and burned from [[Stress corrosion cracking]] (SCC) on March 4, killing 17 people. At least 9 others were injured, and 7 homes 450 feet from the rupture were destroyed. This accident, and others of the era, led then-President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] to call for the formation of a national pipeline safety agency in 1967. The same pipeline had also had an explosion on May 9, 1955, just {{convert|930|ft|m}} from the 1965 failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/louisiana/53/natchitoches,-la-gas-pipeline-explosion,-mar-1965|title=Natchitoches, LA Gas Pipeline Explosion, Mar 1965|work=GenDisasters ... Genealogy in Tragedy, Disasters, Fires, Floods|accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0C1FFE3E5812738DDDAC0894DB405B858AF1D3 | work=The New York Times | title=BLAST FATAL TO 17 IN LOUISIANA CITY; Pipeline Explodes, Spraying Flames Over Homes | date=March 5, 1965}}</ref><ref name="google86">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bW8eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=o8kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=905,3508674&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Daytona Beach Morning Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google87">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jiJLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aCMNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6968,2455002&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Press-Courier - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google88">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=e95dAAAAIBAJ&sjid=x14NAAAAIBAJ&pg=6377,556265&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Washington Observer - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 A crude oil pipeline ruptured east of [[Blanding, Utah]] on April 3, spilling about {{convert|5000|oilbbl|m3}} of crude oil into the [[San Juan River (Colorado River)|San Juan River]]. The ruptured pipeline was reported to flow "wide open" for over an hour.<ref name="google89">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TdhSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1X8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7018,996984&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Deseret News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 On April 28, a butane pipeline ruptured in [[Conroe, Texas]], forcing residents in an 8 block area to evacuate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19650429&id=07ozAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nPcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2755,7220552&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}</ref> * 1965 On July 24, a natural gas pipeline exploded and burned when workers were welding on a tie-in pipeline onto it near [[Tescott, Kansas]]. One of the workers died, and 15 others were injured.<ref name="google90">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ynwoAAAAIBAJ&sjid=T8kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=880,5098179&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Daytona Beach Morning Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 On August 21, a 9-year-old girl was killed and eight people were injured in a [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline explosion in western [[Van Wert County, Ohio]]. The explosion threw up flames that could be seen from {{convert|40|mi|km}} away and scorched a {{convert|100|acre|km2|adj=on}} area of farmland. A home about 800 yards away was shifted off of its foundation, and half a mile of railroad ties set on fire. The girl was killed in her bed in a house 300 yards from the blast site. The rest of her family was injured. Investigators said the explosion was caused by gas leaking from an 8-inch pipeline, and was apparently ignited by a spark from a passing train.<ref name="google91">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yaEyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BusFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5966,1540001&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Miami News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thevwindependent.com/news/2015/08/elgin-propane-gas-explosion-remembered-50-years-later/|title=Elgin propane gas explosion remembered|work=The VW independent}}</ref> * 1965 An 8-inch diameter [[Buckeye Partners]] gasoline pipeline ruptured in [[Sylvania, Ohio]] on August 23. The danger of fire or explosion forced evacuations of residents in a {{convert|2|sqmi|km2|adj=on}} area. There was no fire.<ref name="google92">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V1tQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OQ4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4744,7961331&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 On October 25, a ruptured [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline spilled naphtha in [[Mount Cory, Ohio]], forcing evacuations until the naphtha evaporated.<ref name="google93">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fS5JAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2YMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3962,3294397&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Youngstown Vindicator - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1965 In November, 2 workers cutting into a pipeline at a [[natural gas liquids]] storage facility in [[Mont Belvieu, Texas]] accidentally caused an explosion and fire, killing both workers, forcing 1,700 residents to evacuate, and causing petrochemical businesses in the area to shut down.<ref name="google94">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19651105&id=LiMcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VlkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7084,1945190|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * A survey by the [[Federal Power Commission]] of 51 gas pipeline companies show that between January 1, 1950, and June 30, 1965 showed that gas transmission pipeline failures had killed 64 people and injured another 222. of the fatalities, 35 were gas pipeline company workers or contractors, and 29 were members of the public.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1967/01/22/89658930.pdf | work=The New York Times | first=Gene | last=Smith | title=NADER STRESSES PIPELINE SAFETY; Explosion in Queens Viewed as Having Far-Reaching Impact on Gas Group JOHNSON PLEA PRAISED Crusader Urges That Entire Industry Keep Up Lines, 'Just as Roads Do' | date=January 22, 1967}}</ref> * 1966 On January 10, a new 36 inch gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned during cleaning operations near [[Larose, Louisiana]], killing 2 pipeline workers and burning 5 others.<ref name="google95">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19660111&id=4XVPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BQUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4421,2487219|title=Ocala Star-Banner - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1966 A 6-inch natural gas pipeline ruptured in [[Norfolk, Nebraska]] on January 28, shutting off gas to 20,000 people in 10 communities on January 28.<ref name="google96">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rBwrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u50FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3114,7140417&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Reading Eagle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1966 On July 1, a break in an 8-inch [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline Co. line spilled thousands of gallons of crude into a field and the sewer system of [[Findlay, Ohio]].<ref name="google97">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19660630&id=qedOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aAEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7062,3098667|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1966 On December 14, a leaking propane pipeline near [[Swedenborg, Missouri]] made a car stall. Others came to aid the stalled car, and someone lit a cigarette, igniting the fumes. 8 people were burned and hospitalized.<ref name="google98">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=T1wfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bNQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1031,4897538&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Nevada Daily Mail - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 A [[Shell Oil Company]] 6-inch propane pipeline exploded and burned while it was being worked on in [[Meeker, Oklahoma]] on January 10. One of the workers was killed, and another injured.<ref name="google99">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GshDAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GK8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=5823,615002&dq=propane+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Altus Times-Democrat - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 A leaking gas main in the Jamaica section of [[New York City, New York]] caught fire on January 13. 2 pieces of [[FDNY]] equipment responding to the gas leak report were burned, as well as numerous buildings. The fire spread to 13 alarm size, with 63 fire companies being used to control the situation. 17 homes were destroyed. The cause of the leak was the failure of a moisture scrubbing "drip pot" on the pipeline.<ref name="google100">{{cite book|title=Responding to Routine Emergencies|author=Montagna, F.C.|date=1999|publisher=Fire Engineering|isbn=9780912212814|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqRIRCyWSRgC|page=86|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google101">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=f3BIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I1wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7067,2414862&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=St. Petersburg Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google102">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8zhWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7ugDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6242,4456137&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 Manufacturers Light and Heat Company announced they were requesting to the Federal Power Commission permission to allow a new pipeline to replace 73.5 miles of older pipeline, which was having 200 to 450 leaks a year in Eastern Pennsylvania.<ref name="google103">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1kkmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SP8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1009,1979679&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Gettysburg Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 On May 16, a pile driver ruptured a propane pipeline in [[Dearborn, Michigan]]. The escaping gas caught fire, with 2 construction workers being killed, and 4 others seriously burned.<ref name="google104">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HFYlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5asFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4949,1632474&dq=propane+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Owosso Argus-Press - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 A leaking pipeline released {{convert|30000|oilbbl|m3}} of JP-4 grade jet fuel in [[Wilmington, California]] on June 30. There was no fire.<ref name="google105">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1QlSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8DQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6819,430892&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Press-Courier - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 On August 5, a leaking gas main forced 5 homes to be evacuated in [[Queens, New York]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1967/08/06/94109923.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=Gas Leak in Queens | date=August 6, 1967}}</ref> * 1967 On August 10, a gas main that had been capped the day before leaked natural gas into a concession stand in [[Bamberg, South Carolina]]. An explosion of the gas was likely caused by an electrical spark, but the 6:40 am time likely prevented any injuries.<ref name="google106">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19670811&id=9nssAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yswEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4182,1742904|title=Herald-Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1967 A road construction machine ruptured an 18-inch [[Plantation Pipeline]] on September 25 in [[Akron, Alabama]], spilling more than 5,000 gallons of gasoline. The gasoline had to be burned off to eliminate it.<ref name="google107">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19670927&id=Yg4fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I5sEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7162,4640244|title=The Tuscaloosa News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 On the night of January 8, a City Water crew in [[Reading, Pennsylvania]] snagged a 3/4 inch gas line, causing it to pull out of a gas main 14 feet away. About 2 hours later, there was an explosion that destroyed 2 nearby semidetached homes, killing 9 people in those structures.<ref name="ntsb">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/doclib/reports/1971/PSS711.pdf|date=14 December 2012|title=Special study of effects of delay in shutting down failed pipeline systems and methods of providing rapid shutdown|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 A petroleum products pipeline was discovered to be leaking on January 27, near [[Kokomo, Mississippi]]. Damage to cotton crops and water wells was discovered soon afterward.<ref name="findlaw">{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/ga-court-of-appeals/1060181.html|title=PLANTATION PIPELINE COMPANY v. ROYAL INDEMNITY COMPANY - FindLaw|publisher=caselaw.findlaw.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * '''[[Richmond, Indiana explosion]]''': On April 6, 1968, natural gas leaking from a pipeline in [[Richmond, Indiana]] built up in a sporting goods store and exploded. Gunpowder in that store exploded later on. 42 people were killed, 150 were injured, and 15 buildings destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gendisasters.com/data1/in/explosions/richmond-gasexplosion-apr1968.htm|title=Indiana|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="google108">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19680408&id=hi8xAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lgEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7348,6721892|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 On April 15, gasoline odor was detected at a drinking fountain in [[Glendale, California]]. The water well that fed the fountain was determined to be contaminated from an 8-inch pipeline that was leaking. Between 100,000 and {{convert|250,000|USgal|L}} of gasoline were leaked into the local groundwater.<ref name="google109">{{cite book|title=Leak Prevention and Corrective Action Technology for Underground Storage Tanks|author=Gangadharan, A.C.|date=1988|publisher=Noyes Data Corporation|isbn=9780815511632|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Okl1P0IBNfAC|page=250|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 On May 29, a bulldozer ruptured a 1-inch gas service line at a children's nursery in [[Hapeville, Georgia]]. The bulldozer operator was unable to find the shutoff valve for the gas line, and shortly after there was an explosion and fire. Seven children and two adults were killed, and three children were seriously injured in the accident.<ref name="ntsb.gov">{{cite web | url =https://app.ntsb.gov/doclib/reports/1971/PSS711.pdf | title =REPORT NUMBER NTSB-PSS-71-1 - SPECIAL STUDY OF EFFECTS OF DELAY IN SHUTTING DOWN FAILED PIPELINE SYSTEMS AND METHODS OF PROVIDING RAPID SHUTDOWN - Approved DECEMBER 30, 1970 | last1 = | first1 = | author-link1 = | last2 = | first2 = | author-link2 = | date =1971-02-02 | year = | website = | publisher =[[National Transportation Safety Board]] | access-date =2016-01-18 | subscription = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/georgia/12237/hapeville-ga-broken-gas-main-explodes-may-1968|title=Hapeville, GA Broken Gas Main Explodes, May 1968|publisher=}}</ref> * 1968 An 8-inch propane pipeline rupture in a landslide ruptured near [[Plainfield, Ohio]] on June 1. 4 different vehicles later drove into the vapor cloud, causing them to stall. One of the vehicle drivers tried to restart their vehicle, igniting the vapor cloud. 2 people were killed, 3 others injured by burns, and 7 buildings and 7 vehicles were destroyed.<ref name="ntsb" /><ref name="ntsb.gov"/><ref name="google110">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RZNPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aVIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4398,3315317&dq=little+big+inch+leak&hl=en|title=The Bryan Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 On July 26, a worker was burned by a natural gas fire while working on a [[Sunoco]] gas pipeline in [[Gettysburg, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="google111">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19680727&id=sDkmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cP4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3062,2957474|title=Gettysburg Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 A contractor laying a new pipeline broke an old pipeline in [[Norwalk, Ohio]] on August 7, spilling gasoline for 4 hours into the [[Huron River (Ohio)|Huron River]].<ref name="google112">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tyZPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oQEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3358,6833494&dq=mobil+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 On August 22, a 16-inch gasoline pipeline ruptured at [[General Mitchell Field]], spilling almost {{convert|200,000|USgal|L}} of gasoline, and forcing closure of one runway. Previous damage to the pipeline by heavy equipment working in the area was identified as the cause of the rupture.<ref name="google113">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EG0jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UigEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4028,2541514&dq=gasoline+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google114">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sAcqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DCgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4708,3550001&dq=gasoline+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 A coal company digging machine hit an 8-inch LPG pipeline in [[Fulton County, Illinois]] on September 3, killing one person and injuring 4 others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/midamericapipeli00netc#page/16/mode/2up|title=Mid-America Pipeline System liquefied petroleum gas pipeline rupture and fire, Donnellson, Iowa, August 4, 1978|publisher=}}</ref> * 1968 2 teen boys shooting a rifle ignited gasoline leaking from a petroleum pipeline pumping station near [[Midland, Pennsylvania]] on November 3. A large brush fire ensued. Both boys had moderate burns. A stuck relief valve on the pipeline was the cause of the leakge.<ref name="google115">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KURAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DLMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2495,631166&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Beaver County Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google116">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=K0RAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DLMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4087,890463&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Beaver County Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1968 A MAPCO LPG pipeline, near [[Yutan, Nebraska]] ruptured on December 5. Repair crews responded to the pipeline rupture, and thought LPG vapors were dispersed, but ignited the vapor cloud by driving into it. Five repairmen were killed when the vapor cloud ignited. After the accident, the Nebraska State Fire Marshal ordered MAPCO to reduce its operating pressure, and to hydrostatic retest {{convert|52|mi|km}} of that pipeline. During the tests, 195 longitudinal seams failed.<ref name="ntsb.gov"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/nebraska/16567/yutan-ne-gas-pipeline-explosion-dec-1968|title=Yutan, NE Gas Pipeline Explosion, Dec 1968|publisher=}}</ref> * 1968 On December 18, a 30-inch gas pipeline exploded and burned at a gas processing plant in [[Gibson, Louisiana]]. One plant worker was injured.<ref name="google117">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5-dHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Hv8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=4249,7176960&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Morning Record - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1969 On January 3, a gas explosion hit under a [[Manhattan]] borough street in [[New York City, New York]], followed by a number of other gas explosions. 300 families were evacuated, and streets were cracked for 4 blocks. Difficulties of interconnected gas mains caused a 7 delay in shutting down the gas in the area.<ref name="ntsb.gov"/> * 1969 On January 13, a [[Buckeye Partners]] 22-inch crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Lima, Ohio]], spilling 1,000 to 2,000 barrels of oil on a street and into the sewer system. 8,500 people were evacuated. The crude caught fire, damaging the sewerage treatment plant. Cracks from welding were blamed for the failure.<ref name="ntsb"/><ref name="google118">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kdBOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CQIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4267,2126544&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1969/01/14/77430986.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=10,000 EVACUATED IN OHIO OIL FLOOD; Fuel, Leaking From a Lima Pipeline, Causes Fires | date=January 14, 1969}}</ref> * 1969 A leaking crude oil pipeline caused a slick {{convert|35|mi|km}} long in the Dry Creek near [[Greybull, Wyoming]] on February 24.<ref name="google119">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cLZWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fOkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4837,1893118&dq=marathon+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1969 A 10-inch pipeline carrying aviation gasoline was ruptured by explosives on March 17 in [[Canyon, California]] The fuel caught fire shortly after that.<ref name="google120">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xekrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tgUGAAAAIBAJ&pg=1385,5869510&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Kentucky New Era - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1969 On April 18, a gas explosion destroyed a home in [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]], killing 2 children. Damage by a contractor to the gas lines and gas mains in the area was suspected as the cause.<ref name="google121">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19700129&id=uu4aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lUYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7144,3975241|title=Daily News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1969 On May 6, a gas pipeline in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], that had been moved, was undergoing pressure testing when a cap on it blew off, hitting and rupturing another nearby gas pipeline. That pipeline exploded and burned, killing 1 worker, injuring 9 other workers, and damaging 3 homes.<ref name="google122">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DYNiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cXcNAAAAIBAJ&pg=890,717328&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Observer-Reporter - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1969 The over pressure of a low pressure natural gas distribution system in [[Gary, Indiana]] caused numerous small fires and explosions. A gas company worker's errors allowed much higher than normal gas pressure in a gas distribution system. 56 square blocks were evacuated, 7 people were injured, 6 homes destroyed, and 19 other homes damaged. Later, The National Transportation Safety Board called for upgraded gas pipeline safety standards.(June 3, 1969)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/PAR1969.aspx|title=Pipeline Accident Report 1969 (not numbered)|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="google123">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4XssAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2cwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5745,783969&dq=gary+gas+explosion&hl=en|title=Herald-Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1970/02/18/129332492.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=Gas Pipeline Safety Called Inadequate | date=February 18, 1970}}</ref> * 1969 On September 9, a converted natural gas pipeline running at 789 psi near [[Houston, Texas]] ruptured, causing a massive fire. Construction work downstream of the accident led to a pressure build up that caused the rupture. 7 people were injured, 13 homes were destroyed, and 11 other homes damaged. Some of the homes were within 25 feet of the pipeline. The closest valves on this pipeline took 90 minutes to close.<ref name="ntsb.gov"/><ref name="google125">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=T94jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TygEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7474,4746423&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1969 On September 23, a bulldozer being used as part of high tension power line construction hit a gas transmission pipeline in [[Proctor, West Virginia]]. The gas exploded and burned, injuring 6 of the electrical line construction crew. Another bulldozer had also hit a gas pipeline in the same area some months before, killing another worker.<ref name="google126">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19690924&id=euhdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H18NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3775,3161026|title=Observer-Reporter - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * On November 6, 1969, a bulldozer partially collapsed the steel covers of a gas regulator pit, in [[Burlington, Iowa]]. This caused damaged to the regulator, caused a five times pressure surge in the gas distribution system. gas fire caused major damage to 10 homes, and, minor damage to 42 homes.<ref>https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-70-029</ref> * 1969 On November 19, telephone company contractors installing an underground cable hit a 10-inch gas pipeline in [[Vandyne, Wisconsin]]. Gas at 750 psi escaped, and ignited about 45 minutes later, killing one of the contractors, and injuring 3 others.<ref name="ntsb"/> * 1969 On December 25, a land leveler ruptured a 22-inch natural gas transmission pipeline, in [[Hermiston, Oregon]]. Gas at 600 psi sprayed from the pipeline. A warning sign about the existence of the gas pipeline was {{convert|10|ft|m}} away from the rupture site.<ref name="google127">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dnozAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2889,6351586&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Eugene Register-Guard - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref>
==1970–1974==
* 1970 On January 11, a home exploded in [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]], killing a man. Contractor damage to a gas line was suspected.<ref name="google121"/> * 1970 On January 17, workers from [[Buckeye Partners]] ignited a fire to burn off petroleum from a leaking pipeline near [[Warren, Ohio]]. The fire grew out of control for several hours, requiring 100 firefighters to help contain the blaze. One pipeline employee was injured.<ref name="google128">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19700118&id=OylPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tgEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1926,5231114|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1970 A leaking 2 inch natural gas main exploded in [[Houma, Louisiana]] on January 24, killing 2 gas company workers, one firefighter, injuring 28 others, and demolishing half a block of downtown buildings. The workers were attempting to repair the gas line.<ref name="ntsb.gov"/><ref name="google129">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MexKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HyMNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5066,5057982&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Press-Courier - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google130">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=j55YAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hvgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5784,3867032&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1970 On February 5, a jet fuel pipeline leaked, and contaminated 50 to 60 acres of farm and pasture land near [[Lakeland, Florida]]. Some wildlife was killed, and a small fire broke out in the fuel.<ref name="google131">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rZVPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SgUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5676,5906974&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Ocala Star-Banner - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google132">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g_IsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KGYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6098,2140761&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Sarasota Herald-Tribune - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1970 An 8-inch pipeline broke near [[Wauseon, Ohio]] on April 19, spilling Number 2 fuel oil into the [[Maumee River]], and endangering the water supply for several cities for a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19700420&id=xyYxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uQEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5162,5777967|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> * 1970 Early on September 2, residents of Jacksonville, Maryland, detected gasoline odors and noticed gasoline in a small creek flowing beneath a nearby road. Because fumes were still present in the late afternoon of September 2, a resident notified [[Colonial Pipeline]] at 6:19 p.m. about the situation. About 12 hours later, on the morning of September 3, an explosion and fire occurred in a ditch in which contractor personnel for Colonial were manually digging to further expose the pipeline & catch gasoline trickling from the ground. Five persons were injured, none fatally. The NTSB later pointed out that workers had failed to use a flammable vapor percent detector during the work. The leak point was found 4 days later. The failure resulted in a release of 30,186 gallons (718 barrels) of gasoline and kerosene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/PAR7102.aspx|title=Pipeline Accident Report PAR-71-02|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="google133">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FaRRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vhAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3600,500912&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Sentinel - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1970 On September 7, a pipeline leaked thousands of gallons of gasoline onto farmland near [[Ontario, Oregon]]. Roads were closed in the area until the gasoline was removed.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oggxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LeEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5894,1738316&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en ]{{dead link|date=January 2016}}</ref> * 1970 The [[1970 Propane vapor cloud explosion in Port Hudson]]. On December 9, 1970, a [[Phillips Petroleum Company]] [[propane]] pipeline leaked, in [[Franklin County, Missouri]]. The leak led a to propane cloud explosion, with a force estimated up to 50 tons of [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]]. The NTSB cited past external and internal corrosion issues, and poor welds on the uncoated pipeline as concerns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-72-008|title=Safety Recommendation P-72-008|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="google134">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=p2UfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=w9QEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2640,4723914&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Southeast Missourian - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1970 Explosion of a 30-inch 1100 psi inlet natural gas pipeline, bringing offshore natural gas into a gas drying plant in southern Louisiana. Two plant personnel were killed. Rupture was at a junction of a 12-inch gas line to the 30-inch main line. (December 1970) * 1970 A restaurant owner opened a gas line valve in [[New York, New York]], not knowing that part of the gas line was open and unconnected. The gas in the building exploded, killing 15 people, & injuring more than 60 others. (December 11, 1970)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-71-005|title=Safety Recommendation P-71-005|publisher=}}</ref> * 1970 On December 17, a Mid-Valley pipeline leaked, spilling 250,000 gallons of crude oil onto that companies' land in [[Dayton, Ohio]]. There were no injuries or fire.<ref name="google135">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19701218&id=XvcjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5QEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=705,4309813|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1970 On December 28, a 12-inch pipeline ruptured in [[Jackson, Washington County, Wisconsin|Jackson, Wisconsin]], spilling {{convert|200|oilbbl|m3}} of fuel oil into a wildlife sanctuary.<ref name="google136">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AIhQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uhEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6691,892684&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Sentinel - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1971 A faulty valve on a 3-inch natural gas pipeline was suspected of causing a gas leak that resulted in 3 separate explosions, including a house explosion in [[Lambertville, New Jersey]] that killed 7 people. * 1971 On April 17, a road grader hit a gas transmission pipeline in [[Mississippi]], result in fatal burns to the grader operator. Later, it was found the pipeline only had 5 to 6 inches of soil cover in the area.<ref name="openjurist">{{cite web|url=http://openjurist.org/507/f2d/658/wideman-v-mississippi-valley-gas-company|title=507 F2d 658 Wideman v. Mississippi Valley Gas Company | OpenJurist|publisher=openjurist.org|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1971 On June 5, an ammonia pipeline failed near [[Floral, Arkansas]], releasing 80 tons of ammonia. A 6-year-old boy had to be hospitalized, cattle were killed or blinded, and 10,000 acres of trees had leaf scorching from the ammonia. Delays were made in notifying Arkansas State Department of Pollution Control and Ecology.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1971/07/06/90680420.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=Gas Leak Scars Arkansas Forest; Delay in Reporting Is Studied | date=July 6, 1971}}</ref> * 1971 2 gas explosions occurred in [[North Richland Hills, Texas]], on October 4. Gas migrated into 2 homes from leaking gas pipes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-72-034|title=Safety Recommendation P-72-034|publisher=}}</ref> * 1971 A gas company repair crew was overcome in a service vault on November 17, in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]. 2 workmen were overcome initially, and 4 others attempting to rescue them were also overcome by gas asphyxiation. All 6 died.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-72-025|title=Safety Recommendation P-72-025|publisher=}}</ref> * 1972 On January 7, a huge explosion and fire occurred on a 24-inch gas transmission pipeline west of [[Centerville, Iowa]]. The fire was visible for far around. There were no injuries or major property damage.<ref name="google137">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XopiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rncNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6503,849199&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Telegraph-Herald - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 The second pipeline leak in a month into the [[Tippecanoe River]] in [[Indiana]] on a Buckeye Pipeline company (now [[Buckeye Partners]] ) line hit on January 12. The Buckeye Pipeline was owned by the bankrupt [[Penn Central Railroad]], preventing money from being spent on repairs. One EPA official stated "they know they have a leaky system".<ref name="google138">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=P2JjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Om0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1522,2133488&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=The Rochester Sentinel - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 On January 11, a 10-inch pipeline ruptured in [[Clinton, Montana]], spilling {{convert|3000|oilbbl|m3}} of diesel fuel, with some of it reaching the [[Clark Fork River]].<ref name="google139">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4u9LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Xe0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5134,4512048&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google140">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4e9LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Xe0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5467,4445395&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 The rupture of a 20-inch gas pipeline shut down most of the gas supply for [[Joplin, Missouri]] on January 28. An estimated 25,000 people were affected.<ref name="google141">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=diUzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H-cFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1621,3271738&dq=propane+pipeline&hl=en|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 During the blowdown of a dehydrator, LPG fumes caught fire at [[Conway, Kansas]] on January 29, killing a pipeline company worker.<ref name="phmsa.dot.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/portal/site/PHMSA/menuitem.ebdc7a8a7e39f2e55cf2031050248a0c/?vgnextoid=fdd2dfa122a1d110VgnVCM1000009ed07898RCRD&vgnextchannel=3430fb649a2dc110VgnVCM1000009ed07898RCRD&vgnextfmt=print|title=PHMSA - Data & Statistics - Distribution, Transmission & Gathering, LNG, and Liquid Accident and Incident Data|publisher=phmsa.dot.gov|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 A [[Colonial Pipeline]] pipeline ruptured in [[Cobb County, Georgia]] on February 2, spilling about 2,000 gallons of fuel oil into the [[Chattahoochee River]] upstream of a water intake for the city of [[Atlanta]].
