Much work went into keeping the spill from the water intake. There were no injuries.<ref name="google142">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jQMdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QJwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7308,526948&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Tuscaloosa News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 On February 12, a [[Conoco]] pipeline rupture spilled {{convert|16,000|USgal|L}} of diesel fuel into the [[Spokane River]] near [[Spokane, Washington]].<ref name="google143">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qHRhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6OwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4510,157431&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google144">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iahYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1833,4042429&dq=conoco+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google145">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19720216&id=lKdYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pvgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1586,15132|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 On March 24, a 2-inch steel gas main was pulled out of a compression coupling, at [[Annandale, Virginia]], causing a leak. Natural gas later exploded, killing 3 people, injuring one other person, and, destroying 2 homes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P72_40_62.pdf|title=P72_40_62<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref> * 1972 On June 15, a crew was welding on a gas main in [[Bryan, Ohio]] that had been shut off, when someone inadvertently opened a valve that fed gas into that main. The gas ignited, and exploded, serious injuring 2 workers.<ref name="google146">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nJZPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RFIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4233,1138092&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Bryan Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 A 12-inch diameter high pressure propane pipeline, near [[Butler, Alabama]], was ruptured by a road grader. A short time after the line was ruptured, a car drove into the vapor cloud. The car stalled, and trying to restart it was suspected to have ignited the vapor cloud, killing four people. (June 20, 1972)<ref name="phmsa.dot.gov"/><ref name="google147">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CQ8fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JpwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7034,2937516&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Tuscaloosa News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/alabama/12986/butler-al-gas-line-explosion-june-1972|title=Butler, AL Gas Line Explosion, June 1972|publisher=}}</ref> * 1972 A gasoline pipeline ruptured and ignited at a [[Plantation Pipeline]] Terminal in [[Bremen, Georgia]] on September 6. For a time, there were fears the fire might spread to nearby fuel storage tanks, but the fire was limited to the pipeline.<ref name="google148">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IQJfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aWQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2762,472152&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Waycross Journal-Herald - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 On October 10, a crude oil spill was spotted coming from a leaking oil pipeline off of [[Grand Isle, Louisiana]]. About 8,000 barrels of crude were spilled.<ref name="google149">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8GxkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GX0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1120,935465&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Calgary Herald - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 On October 10, a Texas-New Mexico Pipeline Company crude oil pipeline ruptured near [[Shiprock, New Mexico]], spilling {{convert|285,000|USgal|L}} of crude oil into the San Juan River, polluting it for 100 miles. Later, it was discovered that the pipeline company had increased pressure on the pipeline before the rupture to make up for an earlier pipeline shut down.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/pingnews/451584343/|title=Public Domain: Documerica: Texas-New Mexico Pipeline Burst, 1972 by David C. Hiser (NARA/EPA)|work=Flickr - Photo Sharing!}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/7665679-video-thieves-accidentally-blown-up-an-oil-pipeline-killed-22-in-mexico/image/60963400-upper-end-of-log-boom-on-san-juan-river-in-monument-valley-utah-boom-was-the-site-of-clean-|title=Pulsepoint|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="google150">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=886&dat=19721015&id=K7taAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UlADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5331,5570522|title=The Prescott Courier - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 On October 30, a bulldozer working on a power company construction project ruptured a gas main in [[Lake City, Minnesota]]. Leaking gas accumulated in, then exploded, in a nearby variety store, killing 6 and injuring 9.<ref name="google151">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UAJfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aWQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6140,6309607&dq=gasline+blast&hl=en|title=Waycross Journal-Herald - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1972 A leak in a weld on a 36-inch gas transmission pipeline on November 18 in [[Bend, Oregon]] forced the shutdown of gas service to 3,000 customers.<ref name="google152">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=z1NYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gvcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3518,4693411&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=The Bulletin - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 On January 10, an abandoned farm near [[Bellingham, Washington]] was coated in crude oil when a Trans-Mountain 16 inch pipeline failed. Over 300,000 gallons of crude were recovered.<ref name="google153">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OFFmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IIsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4190,1837454&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Sun - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 A cracked gas main leaked in [[Adamsville, Alabama]], on February 7. The escaping gas exploded, killing 3 people and injuring 2 others. A string of other gas main cracking incidents occurred in this city, killing one other person, and injuring 2 others.<ref name="ntsb9">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/doclib/recletters/1973/P73_1.pdf|date=18 October 2004|title=P73_1|author=National Transportation Safety Board Safety Recommendation Document|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 Installation of a sewer was suspected of damaging a gas line in [[Coopersburg, Pennsylvania]] on February 21. Leaking gas later exploded in an apartment building, killing 5 people, injuring 22 others, and destroying the building.<ref name="google154">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XCRJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QoQMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4711,2577648&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Youngstown Vindicator - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 On February 22, in [[Austin, Texas]], a 19-inch natural gas liquids (NGL) pipeline ruptured, due to an improper weld. A passing truck appeared to set off a vapor cloud explosion and fire. Six people were killed, and 2 others injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P73_47_54.pdf |format=PDF |title=Recommendations |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref><ref name="google155">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_KpVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JOEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5310,5154149&dq=pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Eugene Register-Guard - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google156">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19730224&id=9RxIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9IAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=7165,3648132|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 On May 2, a Yellowstone Pipeline 10-inch line ruptured in [[Murray, Idaho]], causing a mist of diesel fuel to cover homes and trailers. About 170,000 gallons of fuel were spilled. Some of the fuel reached a nearby creek. There was no fire.<ref name="google157">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1KdYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ovgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6588,1269047&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google158">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EqBfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0jEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4999,945152&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Lewiston Morning Tribune - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google159">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19730612&id=9x5OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Pe0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3704,4716643|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 Improper sampling procedures on an LPG pipeline killed one worker and injured another from freezing at [[Dayton, Ohio]] on May 3.<ref name="phmsa.dot.gov"/> * 1973 On June 2, an [[Exxon]] 12 inch crude oil pipeline started leaking at the [[Atchafalaya River]] near [[Melville, Louisiana]].<ref name="google160">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1842&dat=19730602&id=nQosAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v8YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5031,184028|title=Times Daily - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 In the summer, a pipeline ruptured in [[Diamond, Louisiana]]. The escaping gas fumes were ignited by a lawnmower, killing 2 people.<ref name="google161">{{cite book|title=Diamond: A Struggle for Environmental Justice in Louisiana's Chemical Corridor|author1=Lerner, S.|author2=Bullard, R.D.|date=2006|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=9780262250184|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BNMpKkIa4MsC|page=29|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 A [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline failed near [[Findlay, Ohio]] on June 27, spilling about {{convert|150,000|USgal|L}} of jet aviation fuel into the [[Ottawa Creek]] and the [[Blanchard River]], killing fish & plants. A failed gasket caused the spill.<ref name="google162">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JaRPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wlEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5743,6607051&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=The Bryan Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google163">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2nEUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DQIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2630,572849&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google164">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7HEUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DgIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3748,455534&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google165">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19730717&id=7HEUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DgIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3748,455534|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 On July 4, a gas main explosion set off an apartment house fire, in [[Long Beach, California]], burning two persons. Two others who jumped from windows also were injured. The explosion which occurred after 8:30 p.m., ripped a 40-foot hole in the street and sent flames into the 15-unit structure.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/visuals/photography/la-me-fw-archives-gas-main-explodes-in-long-beach-20170730-story.html</ref> * 1973 On August 29, an 8-inch gas pipeline failed in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], forcing over 100 people to evacuate the area. There was no fire.<ref name="google166">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=757&dat=19730829&id=2rhNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yUQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3711,6169385|title=The Virgin Islands Daily News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 A crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Los Angeles, California]] on October 18. Crude flowed along several streets for a time.<ref name="google167">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jpNYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VvgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1502,1607294&dq=pipeline+rupture&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 On November 13, a [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline leaked, spilling gasoline into [[Marion Township, Berks County, Pennsylvania]] creek.<ref name="google168">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19731114&id=SpghAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NJoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3123,2913445|title=Reading Eagle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1973 On December 4, a pipeline break released {{convert|31000|oilbbl|m3}} of oil near [[Argyle, Minnesota]]. The cause was a failure in a longitudinal weld.<ref name="businessnorth.com">{{cite web | url =http://www.businessnorth.com/exclusives.asp?RID=3219 | title =BusinessNorth Exclusives - Alberta-Superior pipeline takes center stage in world climate debate | last1 =Thomas | first1 =Richard | author-link1 = | last2 = | first2 = | author-link2 = | date =2009-10-27 | year = | website = BusinessNorth.com | publisher =BusinessNorth | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20141102001542/http://www.businessnorth.com/exclusives.asp?RID=3219 | archive-date =2014-11-02 | access-date =2016-01-18 | subscription = }}</ref> * 1973 On December 6, a pump station on an ammonia pipeline near [[Conway, Kansas]], was started against a closed valve, and the pipeline failed in a previously damaged section. Two persons who drove through the ammonia vapors were hospitalized; several rural residents were evacuated from the area and {{convert|89,796|USgal|L}} of anhydrous ammonia were lost.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P74_50_58.pdf | title =Safety Recommendation P-74-050-58 | last1 = | first1 = | author-link1 = | last2 = | first2 = | author-link2 = | date =1974-11-11 | year = | website = | publisher =[[National Transportation Safety Board]] | access-date =2016-01-18 | subscription = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-74-050|title=Safety Recommendation P-74-050|publisher=National Transportation Safety Board|date=1985-08-19}}</ref> * 1974 A 22-inch natural gas transmission pipeline failed in [[Prairie du Rocher, Illinois]] on January 2. The resulting fire caused no serious damage, but 7,000 people in the area were left without gas heating for several subfreezing days.<ref name="google169">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EbQsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ywkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2492,457896&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Star-News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 On January 25, a pipeline failed near [[Liberty, Texas]], spilling about 200 barrels of oil into the [[Trinity River (Texas)|Trinity River]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1891&dat=19740125&id=ubsfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ttcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3907,3733836|title=Gadsden Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> * 1974 On March 2, a 30-inch gas pipeline failed at 797 pounds pressure inside a 34-inch casing pipe under a road near [[Monroe, Louisiana]]. 10 acres of forest were burned, but there were no injuries or deaths. A substandard girth weld was the cause. The failure of automatic valves on the pipeline to close upon a pressure drop were also cited in contributing to the size of the accident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P75_1_4.pdf |format=PDF |title=Probable Cause |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * 1974 A gas transmission pipeline ruptured near [[Farmington, New Mexico]] on March 15, killing a family of 3 in a truck driving nearby when the gas ignited. Corrosion along the longitudinal seem weld of the pipe section caused the failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_2.pdf |format=PDF |title=Safety Recommendations |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * 1974 A gas line in a commercial building in [[New York, New York]], was ruptured by falling equipment in a basement on April 22. The escaping gas later exploded, injuring more than 70 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_9A_11.pdf |format=PDF |title=Safety Recommendations |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * 1974 A previously damaged gas main ruptured in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] on May 3, causing an explosion that killed 2, and caused extensive damage to 4 row homes. Earlier plumbing work was suspect to have caused the gas line damage.<ref name="google170">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IMotAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cpoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4111,2543650&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Reading Eagle - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 On May 21, a 6-inch gas-gathering pipeline, ruptured at the edge of a rural road south of [[Meridian, Mississippi]]. Three vehicles entered the area which contained the escaping gas, and stalled near the rupture. The gas ignited at 10:05 p.m., and five persons died as a result. The 3 vehicles were destroyed and {{convert|40|acre|m2}} of woodland were burned. Although less than 4 years old, the 6-inch pipe had corroded internally and had been embrittled by hydrogen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_5.pdf|title=P76_5<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref> * 1974 A 30-inch [[Transcontinental Pipeline]] gas transmission pipeline failed and gas ignited near [[Bealeton, Virginia]], on June 9, from hydrogen stress cracking. Failure alarms at the nearest upstream gas compressor station did not activate, and the pipeline failure was first noticed by a compressor station employee happening to see the large fire from the pipeline rupture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P75_7_11.pdf|title=P75_7_11<!-- Bot generated title -->|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="google171">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9_VNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DosDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1996,2624507&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Free Lance-Star - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 In July, a Lakehead 34 inch pipeline burst near [[Bemidji, Minnesota]], spilling between 125,000 and 210,000 gallons of crude oil.<ref name="google172">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19740715&id=zVoaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6SgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4245,2494258|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 On August 13, an ammonia pipeline failed near [[Hutchinson, Kansas]] after a pump station was started against a closed valve. 3 police officers were treated for ammonia inhalation; approximately 200 persons were evacuated from the area of the vapors; trees, lawns, shrubbery, and crops were chemically burned; and an estimated 11,000 fish were killed. It was found that this pipeline had exceeded the maximum operating pressure before failure.<ref name="ntsb18">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/doclib/recletters/1974/P74_28.pdf|date=18 October 2004|title=P74_28|author=National Transportation Safety Board Safety Recommendation Document|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 September 3, a contractor working to install curb and gutter in the community of [[Dale (CDP), Wisconsin|Dale, Wisconsin]] pulled a gas line apart underneath the town's bank. Gas seeped into the bank's basement and exploded, destroying the bank and the neighboring post office. A bank manager preparing to open the bank for the afternoon was killed, and another resident was seriously injured.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The History of Dale (Poker Flat) and Medina (Young's Corner) Wisconsin|last=Zehner|first=David J.|publisher=Jon Habermann|year=1989|isbn=|location=Neenah, Wisconsin|pages=|asin=B00072ETMG}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/84916188/|title=4 Sep 1974, Page 28 - The La Crosse Tribune at Newspapers.com|website=Newspapers.com|access-date=2016-05-20}}</ref> * 1974 On September 14, a propane pipeline to an underground storage cavern failed in [[Griffith, Indiana]]. The propane later caught fire. 1,000 residents were evacuated during the incident.<ref name="google173">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=84JHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cnwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2745,1744478&dq=propane+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Times-Union - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 A 12-inch gas gathering pipeline exploded and burned near [[Meta, Kentucky]] on November 24. There were no injuries reported. Acts of previous vandalism against the pipeline company had happened before.<ref name="google174">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=O9seAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t0YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4400,4031817&dq=gasline+blast&hl=en|title=Daily News - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google175">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-xJGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ENEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4261,2574835&dq=gathering+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Portsmouth Times - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref> * 1974 A crew repairing a leaking crude oil pipeline near [[Abilene, Texas]], were overcome by sour crude oil fumes on December 1. Six of the repair crew died. The leak was caused by improper welding.<ref name="ntsb19">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/doclib/recletters/1976/P76_30_35.pdf|date=18 October 2004|title=P76_30_35|author=National Transportation Safety Board Safety Recommendation Document |accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="google176">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iWdHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gnwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4557,14305&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Times-Union - Google News Archive Search|publisher=news.google.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist }} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List of pipeline accidents in the United States (1950-74)}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]]

{{Infobox settlement |name = Mist, Oregon |official_name = |settlement_type = [[Unincorporated area|Unincorporated community]] |nickname = |motto =
<!-- Images --> |image_skyline = |imagesize = |image_caption = |image_flag = |image_seal =
<!-- Maps --> |pushpin_map = USA Oregon#USA |pushpin_label = Mist |pushpin_label_position = bottom <!-- the position of the pushpin label: left, right, top, bottom, none --> |pushpin_map_caption = Location within the state of Oregon |pushpin_mapsize = |image_map = |map_caption = Location within Columbia county |image_map1 = |mapsize1 = |map_caption1 =
<!-- Location --> |subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] |subdivision_name = United States |subdivision_type1 = [[U.S. state|State]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Oregon]] |subdivision_type2 = [[List of counties in Oregon|County]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Columbia County, Oregon|Columbia]]
|government_footnotes = |government_type = |leader_title = <!-- Mayor --> |leader_name = |leader_title1 = |leader_name1 = |established_title = |established_date =
<!-- Area --> |unit_pref = Imperial |area_footnotes = |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 =
<!-- Population --> |population_as_of = [[United States Census, 2000|2000]] |population_footnotes = |population_total = |population_density_km2 = auto
<!-- General information --> |timezone = [[Pacific Time Zone|Pacific (PST)]] |utc_offset = -8 |timezone_DST = PDT |utc_offset_DST = -7 |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_ft = |coordinates = {{coord|45|59|47|N|123|15|19|W|region:US_type:city|display=inline,title}}
<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]] |postal_code = 97016 |area_code = [[Area codes 503 and 971|503 and 971]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Mist''' is an [[Unincorporated area|unincorporated community]] in [[Columbia County, Oregon|Columbia County]], [[Oregon]], United States. Formerly called Riverside, the place was renamed in 1888 for the atmospheric conditions of the [[Nehalem River|Nehalem Valley]].<ref name=ogn>{{cite OGN|7th|page=652}}</ref> The first land claims in the area had been made circa 1870.<ref name=journal>{{cite journal|title=Tracking the Kerry Line: Evidence From a Logging Railroad Camp in the Nehalem Valley, Oregon|author1=Connolly, Thomas J. |author2=Bland, Richard L. |author3=Tonsfeldt, Ward |journal=Journal of Northwest Anthropology|date=Fall 2011|volume=45|issue=22|pages=199–208|url=http://www.northwestanthropology.com/article_files/Final%20with%20Cover.pdf|format=PDF|issn=1538-2834|publisher=Northwest Anthropology|location=Richland, Washington|accessdate=February 26, 2014}}</ref> The original Riverside post office was closed in 1975.<ref name=ogn/>
On July 6, 2001, the Mist store, which was built in 1874, caught fire and was destroyed. Until then, it was the oldest continuously operating business in Oregon,<ref>[http://home.comcast.net/~jbutts14/mist.html The Nehalem River Highway], Jeffrey Butts</ref> offering food and hardware and displaying historic newspaper clippings and antique logging equipment on the walls.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
Mist is a crossroads community where [[Oregon Route 47]] turns north to [[Clatskanie, Oregon|Clatskanie]], and a pioneer trail (Burn Road) crossed the Nehalem River and went south to [[Vernonia, Oregon|Vernonia]]. It is the eastern terminus of [[Oregon Route 202]]. The Nehalem River valley widens between Mist and [[Jewell, Oregon|Jewell]] and was favored by the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] tribes of the area for hunting; it was later favored by early [[European American]] settlers for agriculture.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} Although the area is now sparsely settled, it is notable for having the largest operating [[sawmill]] in Columbia County and also geological conditions lending themselves to [[natural gas storage]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} Mist contains one of the very few, and therefore very valuable, natural gas storage areas in the [[Pacific Northwest]]. It operates unobtrusively{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} on a hill near Mist. It is controlled by [[NW Natural]] (formerly Northwest Natural Gas) and is connected by several pipelines, including a {{convert|16|in|mm|adj=on}} and a {{convert|24|in|mm|adj=on}} pipeline along the [[Nehalem Highway]].<ref>[http://www.snl.com/Cache/3683199.PDF?FID=3683199&O=PDF&T=&D=&IID=4057132&Y= Northwest Natural 2006 Annual report]</ref>
Earlier in the 20th century, Mist had a logging camp next to a railroad used by the Kerry Timber and Logging Company. The remains of the camp were discovered in 2008 and 2009.<ref name=journal/> Though still important in terms of logging, the population today is sparse, and there is no longer a railroad.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
[[Image:SnowyNightInMist.jpg|thumb|600px|center|Panorama of a snowy night in Mist, taken early 2006.]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2008}}
==External links== *[http://www.vannattabros.com/geo3.html History of Mist from VanNatta Forestry] *[http://www.vernonia.k12.or.us/node/247 Mist Elementary School] *[http://photos.salemhistory.net/cdm4/results.php?CISOOP1=all&CISOBOX1=&CISOFIELD1=title&CISOOP2=exact&CISOBOX2=Mist,%20Oregon&CISOFIELD2=subjec&CISOOP3=any&CISOBOX3=&CISOFIELD3=descri&CISOOP4=none&CISOBOX4=&CISOFIELD4=audiena&CISOROOT=all Historic photos of Mist from Salem Public Library]

revision.comment: /* Calcium carbonate scale */ Le Chatelier name is written with only one L: Le Chatellier —> Le Chatelier; correction of the wiki link
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2016}}
'''Oilfield scale inhibition''' is the process of preventing the formation of [[fouling|scale]] from blocking or hindering fluid flow through pipelines, valves, and pumps used in oil production and processing. [[Descaling agent|Scale inhibitors]] (SIs) are a class of specialty chemicals that are used to slow or prevent scaling in water systems.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alzahrani|first=Salem|last2=Mohammad|first2=Abdul Wahab|date=2014-12-01|title=Challenges and trends in membrane technology implementation for produced water treatment: A review|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214714414001093|journal=Journal of Water Process Engineering|volume=4|pages=107–133|doi=10.1016/j.jwpe.2014.09.007}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> Oilfield scaling is the [[Precipitation hardening|precipitation]] and accumulation of insoluble crystals (salts) from a mixture of incompatible [[Aqueous solution|aqueous]] phases in oil processing systems.<ref name=":1" /> {{em|Scale}} is a common term in the [[oil industry]] used to describe solid deposits that grow over time, blocking and hindering fluid flow through pipelines, valves, pumps etc. with significant reduction in production rates and equipment damages.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liang|first=Bin|last2=Pan|first2=Kai|last3=Li|first3=Li|last4=Giannelis|first4=Emmanuel P.|last5=Cao|first5=Bing|date=2014-08-15|title=High performance hydrophilic pervaporation composite membranes for water desalination|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916414002793|journal=Desalination|volume=347|pages=199–206|doi=10.1016/j.desal.2014.05.021}}</ref> Scaling represents a major challenge for [[flow assurance]] in the oil and gas industry. Examples of oilfield scales are calcium carbonate ([[limescale]]), iron sulfides, barium sulfate and strontium sulfate. Scale inhibition encompasses the processes or techniques employed to treat scaling problems.<ref name=":1" />
== Background == [[File:Limescale-in-pipe.jpg|alt=|thumb|Scale build-up effectively decreases pipeline diameter and reduces flow rate]] The three prevailing water-related problems that upset oil companies today are corrosion, gas hydrates and scaling in production systems.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Formation, removal, and inhibition of inorganic scale in the oilfield environment|last=W. Frenier|first=Wayne|publisher=Society of Petroleum Engineers|year=2008|isbn=1555631401|location=http://catdir.loc.gov/catdir/toc/fy12pdf01/2009517707.html|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite book|title=Production chemicals for the oil and gas industry|last=|date=6 Feb 2014|publisher=CRC press.|year=|isbn=9781439873793|location=|pages=|via=|last1=Kelland,|first1=M. A.}}</ref> The reservoir water has a high composition of dissolved minerals equilibrated over millions of years at constant physicochemical conditions. As the reservoir fluids are pumped from the ground, changes in temperature, pressure and chemical composition shift the equilibria and cause precipitation and deposition of sparingly soluble salts that build up over time with the potential of blocking vital assets in the oil production setups.<ref name=":9">{{Cite book|title=Formation, removal, and inhibition of inorganic scale in the oilfield environment|last=Wayne W Frenier, Murtaza Ziauddin, N. Wolf (Editor), Ryan Hartman (Editor)|first=|publisher=Society of Petroleum Engineers|year=2008|isbn=1555631401|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> Scaling can occur at all stages of oil/gas production systems (upstream, midstream and downstream) and causes blockages of well-bore perforations, casing, pipelines, pumps, valves etc. Severe scaling issues have been reported in Russia and certain North Sea production systems.<ref>{{cite journal|last2=Grist|first2=D.M.|last3=Boyle|first3=M.J.|date=May 1980|title=Chemical Treatments Associated with North Sea Projects|journal=Society of Petroleum Engineers|volume=32|issue=05|pages=904–912|doi=10.2118/7880-PA|last1=Mitchell|first1=R.W}}</ref>
== Types of scales == Two main classifications of scales are known; inorganic and organic scales and the two types are mutually inclusive, occurring simultaneously in the same system, referred to as mixed scale.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":9" /> Mixed scales may result in highly complexly structured scales that are difficult to treat. Such scales require aggressive, severe and sometimes costly remediation techniques.<ref name=":0" /> [[Paraffin wax]], [[asphaltene]]s and [[Clathrate hydrate|gas hydrates]] are the most often encountered organic scales in the oil industry. This article focuses on the simplest and common form of scales encountered; inorganic scales.
=== Inorganic scale === Inorganic scales refer to [[Mineral|mineral deposits]] that occur when the formation water mixes with different [[brine]]s such as injection water. The mixing changes causes reaction between incompatible ions and changes the thermodynamic and equilibrium state of the reservoir fluids. [[Supersaturation]] and subsequent deposition of the inorganic salts occur. The most common types of inorganic scales known to the oil/gas industry are [[Carbonate minerals|carbonates]] and [[Sulfate minerals|sulfates]]; [[Sulfide minerals|sulfides]] and [[Chlorite group|chlorites]] are often encountered.
While, the solubility of most inorganic salts (NaCl, KCl, ...) increases with temperature (endothermic dissolution reaction) , some inorganic salts such as calcium carbonate and calcium sulfate have also a [[Solubility#Temperature|retrograde solubility]], i.e., their solubility decreases with temperature. In the case of calcium carbonate, it is due to the degassing of CO<sub>2</sub> whose solubility decreases with temperature as it is the case for most of the gases (exothermic dissolution reaction in water). In the case of calcium sulfate, the reason is that the dissolution reaction of calcium sulfate itself is exothermic and therefore is favored when the temperature decreases (then, the dissolution heat is more easily evacuated, see [[Le Chatelier's principle]]). In other terms, the solubility of calcium carbonate and calcium sulfate increases at low temperature and decreases at high temperature, as it is also the case for [[calcium hydroxide]] ([[portlandite]]) often referred as a didactic case study to explain the reason of retrograde solubility.
{| class="wikitable" !Name !Chemical Formula !Mineral |- |[[Calcium carbonate]] |CaCO<sub>3</sub> |[[Calcite]], [[aragonite]] |- |[[Calcium sulfate]] |CaSO<sub>4</sub> |[[Anhydrite]], [[gypsum]] (CaSO<sub>4</sub> · 2 H<sub>2</sub>O), [[bassanite]] ([[hemihydrate]] form) (CaSO<sub>4</sub> · 0.5 H<sub>2</sub>O) |- |[[Calcium oxalate]] |CaC<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> |[[Beerstone]] |- |[[Barium sulfate]] |BaSO<sub>4</sub> |[[Baryte|Barite]] |- |[[Magnesium hydroxide]] |Mg(OH)<sub>2</sub> |[[Brucite]] |- |[[Magnesium oxide]] |MgO |[[Periclase]] |- |[[Silicate]]s |Me(Si<sub>n</sub>O<sub>x</sub>) · y H<sub>2</sub>O |Serpentine, [[Aegirine|acmite]], [[gyrolite]], [[gehlenite]], [[amorphous silica]], [[quartz]], [[cristobalite]], [[pectolite]] |- |[[Aluminium hydroxide oxide|Aluminium oxy-hydroxides]] |AlO(OH) |[[Boehmite]], [[gibbsite]], [[diaspore]], [[corundum]] |- |[[Aluminosilicate]]s |Al<sub>x</sub>Si<sub>y</sub>O<sub>z</sub> |[[Analcime|Analcite]], [[cancrinite]], [[noselite]] |- |[[Copper]] |Cu |Metallic copper, [[cuprite]] (Cu<sub>2</sub>O), [[tenorite]] (Cu ) |- |[[Magnetite]] |Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> |Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup> mixed oxide: FeO + Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>
|- |[[Trevorite|Nickel ferrite]] |NiFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> |[[Trevorite]], Ni<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup> mixed oxide: NiO + Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> |- |[[Phosphate]]s |Ca<sub>10</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>6</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub> |[[Hydroxylapatite|Hydroxyapatite]] |}
=== Calcium carbonate scale === Water, noted for its high solvation power can dissolve certain gases such as carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) to form aqueous CO<sub>2(aq)</sub>. Under the right conditions of temperature and/or pressure, H<sub>2</sub>O and CO<sub>2(aq)</sub> molecules react to yield carbonic acid (H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) whose solubility increases at low temperature and high pressure. The slightest changes in pressure and temperature dissolves H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3(aq)</sub> in water according to equation (3) to form hydronium and bicarbonate (HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup><sub>(aq)</sub>) ions. # CO<sub>2(aq)</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>(l)</sub> ↔ H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3(aq)</sub> # H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3(aq)</sub> ↔ H<sup>+</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> + HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> # 2 HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> ↔ CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>(l)</sub> + CO<sub>2(g)</sub> # Ca<sup>2+</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> + CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> ↔ CaCO<sub>3(s)</sub>
The two reactions (2) and (4) describe the equilibrium between bicarbonate ions (HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>), which are highly soluble in water and calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) salt. According to [[Le Chatelier's principle]], drilling operations and extraction of the oil from the well bore decreases the pressure of the formation and the equilibrium shifts to the right (3) to increase the production of CO<sub>2</sub> to offset the change in pressure. After years of oil production, wells may experience significant pressure drops resulting in large CaCO<sub>3</sub> deposits as the equilibrium shifts to offset the pressure changes.<ref name=":0" />
=== Sulfate scales === Sulfates of Group (II) metal ions (M<sup>2+</sup>), generally decrease in solubility down the group. The most difficult scales to remove are those of Barium sulfate because of its high insolubility forming very hard scale deposits. A general representation of the reaction is summarized in reaction:
5. M<sup>2+</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> + SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup><sub>(aq)</sub> → MSO<sub>4(s)</sub>
Sulfate scale usually forms when formation water and injected seawater mix together.<ref name=":1" /> The relationship between these and the degree of supersaturation is crucial in estimating the amount of sulfate salts that will precipitate in the system.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Collins|first=I.R.|date=2002-01-01|title=A New Model for Mineral Scale Adhesion|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/74655-MS|journal=International Symposium on Oilfield Scale|language=english|publisher=Society of Petroleum Engineers|doi=10.2118/74655-ms|isbn=9781555639426}}</ref> Seawater has a high concentration of sulfate ions and mixing with formation water with lots of Ca<sup>2+</sup> and other M<sup>2+</sup> ions in the formation water. Severe problems with sulfate scale are common in reservoirs where seawater has been injected to enhance oil recovery.<ref name=":1" />
Due to its relatively high solubility in water, Calcium sulfate is the easiest sulfate scale to remove chemically as compared to strontium and barium sulfate.<ref name=":1" /> Scale crystals are initially dispersed in production systems until accumulation of stable crystals of insoluble sulfates and scale growth occur at nucleation centers.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crabtree, M., Eslinger, D., Fletcher, P., Miller, M., Johnson, A., & King, G.|first=|year=1999|title=Fighting Scale- prevention and removal|url=|journal=Oilfield Review|volume=11 |issue=3|pages=30–45|via=}}</ref> Uneven pipeline surfaces and production equipment such as pumps and valves cause rapid scale growth to levels that can block pipelines.<ref name=":0" />
The scaling-tendency of an oil-well can be predicted based on the prevailing conditions such as pH, temperature, pressure, ionic strength and the mole fraction of CO<sub>2</sub> in the vapor and aqueous phases.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Oddo|first=J.E.|last2=Tomson|first2=M.B.|date=1994-02-01|title=Why Scale Forms in the Oil Field and Methods To Predict It|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/21710-PA|journal=SPE Production & Facilities|language=english|volume=9|issue=01|pages=47–54|doi=10.2118/21710-pa|issn=1064-668X}}</ref> For instance the saturation index for CaCO<sub>3</sub> scale is calculated using the formula;
F<sub>s</sub>= {[Ca<sup>2+</sup>][CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup>]}/K<sub>sp</sub>
Where F<sub>s</sub> is the scale saturation ratio, defined as the ratio of the activity product to the solubility product of the salt. Activity is defined as the product of the activity coefficients and the concentrations of Ca<sup>2+</sup> and SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> ions. The ionic strength is a measure of the concentration of the dissociated ions dissolved in water also called as “total dissolved solids” (TDS).<ref name=":6" />
== Scale remediation == Different oilfield scale remediation techniques are known but majority are based on three basic themes: # Sulfate ion sequestering from sea injection waters # Chemical or mechanical Scale removal/dissolution # Application of Scale Inhibitors (SIs) for scale prevention The first two methods may be used for short-term treatment and effective for mild-scaling conditions,<ref name=":1" /> however, continuous injection or chemical scale squeeze treatment with SIs have been proven over the years to be the most efficient and cost-effective preventative technique.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laing|first=N.|last2=Graham|first2=G.M.|last3=Dyer|first3=S.J.|date=2003-01-01|title=Barium Sulphate Inhibition in Subsea Systems - The Impact of Cold Seabed Temperatures on the Performance of Generically Different Scale Inhibitor Species|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/80229-MS|journal=International Symposium on Oilfield Chemistry|language=english|publisher=Society of Petroleum Engineers|doi=10.2118/80229-ms|isbn=9781555639556}}</ref>
=== Scale inhibitors === [[File:DTPMP.png|thumb|Chemical Structure of Diethylenetriaminepenta(methylene-phosphonic acid)]] Scale inhibitors are specialty chemicals that are added to oil production systems to delay, reduce and/or prevent scale deposition.<ref name=":0" /> [[acrylic acid]] polymers, [[maleic acid]] polymers and [[phosphonate]]s have been used extensively for scale treatment in water systems due to their excellent solubility, thermal stability and dosage efficiency.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amjad|first=Zahid|last2=Koutsoukos|first2=Petros G.|date=2014-02-17|title=Evaluation of maleic acid based polymers as scale inhibitors and dispersants for industrial water applications|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916413005894|journal=Desalination|volume=335|issue=1|pages=55–63|doi=10.1016/j.desal.2013.12.012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shakkthivel|first=P.|last2=Vasudevan|first2=T.|date=2006-10-02|title=Acrylic acid-diphenylamine sulphonic acid copolymer threshold inhibitor for sulphate and carbonate scales in cooling water systems|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916406010757|journal=Desalination|volume=197|issue=1|pages=179–189|doi=10.1016/j.desal.2005.12.023}}</ref> In the water treatment industry, the major classes of SIs have inorganic phosphate, organophosphorous and organic polymer backbones and common examples are PBTC (phosphonobutane-1,2,4-tricarboxylic acid), [[ATMP]] (amino-trimethylene phosphonic acid) and HEDP (1-hydroxyethylidene-1,1-diphosphonic acid), [[polyacrylic acid]] (PAA), phosphinopolyacrylates (such as PPCA), polymaleic acids (PMA), [[maleic acid]] terpolymers (MAT), [[sulfonic acid]] copolymers, such as SPOCA (sulfonated phosphonocarboxylic acid), polyvinyl sulfonates. Two common oilfield mineral SIs are Poly-Phosphono Carboxylic acid (PPCA) and Diethylenetriamine- penta (methylene phosphonic acid) ([[DTPMP]]).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bezemer|first=Cornelis|last2=Bauer|first2=Karl A.|date=1969-04-01|title=Prevention of Carbonate Scale Deposition: A Well-Packing Technique with Controlled Solubility Phosphates|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/2176-PA|journal=Journal of Petroleum Technology|language=english|volume=21|issue=04|pages=505–514|doi=10.2118/2176-pa|issn=0149-2136}}</ref>
Inhibition of calcium carbonate scale deposition and crystal studies of its polymorphs have been conducted.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Shi|first=Wenyan|last2=Xia|first2=Mingzhu|last3=Lei|first3=Wu|last4=Wang|first4=Fengyun|date=2013-08-01|title=Molecular dynamics study of polyether polyamino methylene phosphonates as an inhibitor of anhydrite crystal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916413002397|journal=Desalination|volume=322|pages=137–143|doi=10.1016/j.desal.2013.05.013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fried|first=Ruth|last2=Mastai|first2=Yitzhak|date=2012-01-01|title=The effect of sulfated polysaccharides on the crystallization of calcite superstructures|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022024811008013|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|volume=338|issue=1|pages=147–151|doi=10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2011.09.044|bibcode=2012JCrGr.338..147F}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shi|first=Wen-Yan|last2=Ding|first2=Cheng|last3=Yan|first3=Jin-Long|last4=Han|first4=Xiang-Yun|last5=Lv|first5=Zhi-Min|last6=Lei|first6=Wu|last7=Xia|first7=Ming-Zhu|last8=Wang|first8=Feng-Yun|date=2012-04-02|title=Molecular dynamics simulation for interaction of PESA and acrylic copolymers with calcite crystal surfaces|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916412000537|journal=Desalination|volume=291|pages=8–14|doi=10.1016/j.desal.2012.01.019}}</ref> Different SIs are designed for specific scaling conditions and biodegradability properties.<ref name=":2" /> The inhibitor molecules essentially bind ions in aqueous phase of production fluids that could potentially precipitate as scales. For instance, to bind positively charged ions in the water, anions must be present in the inhibitor molecular backbone structure and vice versa. Group (II) metal ions are commonly sequestered by SIs with the following functionalities;<ref name=":0" />
- Phosphonate ions (-PO<sub>3</sub>H<sup>−</sup>)
'''-''' Phosphate ions (-OPO<sub>3</sub>H<sup>−</sup>)
- Phosphonate ions (-PO<sub>2</sub>H<sup>−</sup>)
- Sulphonate ions (-SO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>)
- Carboxylate ions (-CO<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>)
A SI with a combination of two or more of these functional groups is more efficient in managing scale problems. Usually the sodium salts of the carboxylic derivatives are synthesized as the anionic derivatives and are known to be the most effective due to their high solubilities.<ref name=":0" /> Interactions of these functional groups tend to prevent the crystal growth sites using dissociated or un-dissociated groups. The dissociation state is determined by the pH of the system, hence knowledge of the pKa values of the chemicals are important for different pH environments.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Graham|first=GM Boak, LS Sorbie, KS|year=2003|title=The influence of formation calcium and magnesium on the effectiveness of generically different barium sulphate oilfield scale inhibitors|url=|journal=SOC PETROLEUM ENG|volume=18|pages=28–44|via=Science Citation Index}}</ref> Again, the inhibition efficiency of the SI depends on its compatibility with other production chemicals such as corrosion inhibitors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lawless|first=T.A.|last2=Bourne|first2=H.M.|last3=Bolton|first3=J.R.|date=1993-01-01|title=Examining the Potential for Corrosion Inhibitor and Scale Inhibitor Compatibility in a Multifunctional Squeeze Strategy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/25167-MS|journal=SPE International Symposium on Oilfield Chemistry|language=english|publisher=Society of Petroleum Engineers|doi=10.2118/25167-ms|isbn=9781555634926}}</ref>
== Environmental considerations == Generally, the environmental impacts of SIs are complicated further by combination of other chemicals applied through exploratory, drilling, well-completion and start-up operations. Produced fluids, and other wastes from oil and gas operations with high content of different toxic compounds are hazardous and harmful to human health, water supplies, marine and freshwater organisms.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.offshore-environment.com/drillwastestream.html|title=Drilling Waste Streams from Offshore Oil and Gas Installations|website=www.offshore-environment.com|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Oilfield water technology.|last=Davies|first=Michael ; P. J. B. Scott|publisher=NACE International|year=2006|isbn=978-1-57590-204-3|location=|pages=523–32|quote=|via=}}</ref> For instance trails of increased turbidity resulting from oil and gas exploratory activities on the eastern shelf of Sakhalin in Russia have been reported with consequential adverse effects on salmon, cod and [[Amphipoda|littoral amphipods]].<ref name="Knudsen">{{Cite journal|last=Knudsen|first=B.L.|last2=Hjelsvold|first2=M.|last3=Frost|first3=T.K.|last4=Svarstad|first4=M.B.E.|last5=Grini|first5=P.G.|last6=Willumsen|first6=C.F.|last7=Torvik|first7=H.|date=2004-01-01|title=Meeting the Zero Discharge Challenge for Produced Water|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/86671-MS|journal=SPE International Conference on Health, Safety, and Environment in Oil and Gas Exploration and Production|language=english|publisher=Society of Petroleum Engineers|doi=10.2118/86671-ms|isbn=9781555639815}}</ref>
Efforts to develop more [[environmentally friendly]] SIs have been made since the late 1990s and an increasing number of such SIs are becoming commercially available.<ref name=":0" /> Recent environmental awareness over the past 15 years has resulted in the production and application of more environmentally friendly SIs, otherwise called 'Green Scale Inhibitors' (GSI).<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Boak|first=Lorraine S.|last2=Sorbie|first2=Ken|date=2010-11-01|title=New Developments in the Analysis of Scale Inhibitors|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/130401-PA|journal=SPE Production & Operations|language=english|volume=25|issue=04|pages=533–544|doi=10.2118/130401-pa|issn=1930-1855}}</ref> These GSIs are designed to have reduced bio-accumulating and high biodegradability properties and therefore reduce pollution of the waters around oil production systems.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":7" /> [[Phosphate ester]] SIs, commonly employed for treating calcium carbonate scales are known to be environmentally friendly but poor inhibition efficiency.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Jordan|first=Myles M.|last2=Sorhaug|first2=Eyvind|last3=Marlow|first3=David|date=2012-11-01|title=Red vs. Green Scale Inhibitors for Extending Squeeze life--A Case Study From the North Sea, Norwegian Sector--Part II|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2118/140752-PA|journal=SPE Production & Operations|language=english|volume=27|issue=04|pages=404–413|doi=10.2118/140752-pa|issn=1930-1855}}</ref> Release of SIs containing Nitrogen and Phosphorus distorts the natural equilibrium of the immediate water body with adverse effects on aquatic life.<ref name=":7" />
Another alternative, polysaccharide SIs meet the requirements for environmentally friendly materials; they contain no Phosphorus or Nitrogen and are noted for their non-toxic, renewable, and biodegradable properties.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pro|first=Danièle|last2=Huguet|first2=Samuel|last3=Arkoun|first3=Mustapha|last4=Nugier-Chauvin|first4=Caroline|last5=Garcia-Mina|first5=José Maria|last6=Ourry|first6=Alain|last7=Wolbert|first7=Dominique|last8=Yvin|first8=Jean-Claude|last9=Ferrières|first9=Vincent|date=2014-11-04|title=From algal polysaccharides to cyclodextrins to stabilize a urease inhibitor|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0144861714005530|journal=Carbohydrate Polymers|volume=112|pages=145–151|doi=10.1016/j.carbpol.2014.05.075}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Jun|last2=Willför|first2=Stefan|last3=Xu|first3=Chunlin|date=2015-01-01|title=A review of bioactive plant polysaccharides: Biological activities, functionalization, and biomedical applications|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2212619814000564|journal=Bioactive Carbohydrates and Dietary Fibre|volume=5|issue=1|pages=31–61|doi=10.1016/j.bcdf.2014.12.001}}</ref> Carboxymethyl inulin (CMI), which is isolated from the roots of [[Elecampane|Inula helenium]] has been used in oil exploration and its very low toxicity<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johannsen|first=F. R|date=2003-01-01|title=Toxicological profile of carboxymethyl inulin|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278691502002132|journal=Food and Chemical Toxicology|volume=41|issue=1|pages=49–59|doi=10.1016/S0278-6915(02)00213-2}}</ref> and crystal growth inhibition power<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kirboga|first=Semra|last2=Öner|first2=Mualla|date=2013-04-16|title=Investigation of calcium carbonate precipitation in the presence of carboxymethyl inulin|url=http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=c3ce27022j|journal=CrystEngComm|language=en|volume=15|issue=18|doi=10.1039/c3ce27022j|issn=1466-8033}}</ref> has been reported for treating calcite scales.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kırboga|first=Semra|last2=Öner|first2=Mualla|date=2012-03-01|title=The inhibitory effects of carboxymethyl inulin on the seeded growth of calcium carbonate|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927776511006151|journal=Colloids and Surfaces B: Biointerfaces|volume=91|pages=18–25|doi=10.1016/j.colsurfb.2011.10.031}}</ref> Examples of poorly biodegradable SIs such as the amino-phosphonate and acrylate-based SIs are being phased-out by stringent environmental regulations as demonstrated in the North sea by Norway zero discharge policy.<ref name="Knudsen"/>
== References == <references />
[[Category:Petroleum industry]] [[Category:Chemistry]]

'''Orange County Parks and Recreation''' is the [[county park]] department in [[Orange County, Florida]], United States. It maintains and operates a number of parks, [[multiuse trail]]s, and community [[recreation center]]s.

Bronson State Forest *Cheney Heights Park *Clarcona Horse Park *Corporal Patrick Deans Park *Crystal Lake Neighborhood Park *Cypress Grove Park *Deputy Brandon Coates Community Park (originally referred to as the John Young Community Park) *Donnybrook Park *Downey Park *Dr. P. {{Infobox scientist |name = Otto Redlich |image = |image_size = |caption =Otto Redlich |birth_date = {{Birth date|1896|11|04}} |birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] |residence = |nationality = [[Austrians|Austrian]] later [[United States|American]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1978|08|14|1896|11|04}} |death_place = [[California]], [[United States]] |field = [[physical chemist]] |work_institution = [[University of Vienna]],
[[Washington State College]]
Shell Development Co.,
[[University of California, Berkeley]] |alma_mater = University of Vienna |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for =[[Redlich-Kwong equation]]
[[Teller-Redlich isotopic product rule|Teller-Redlich rule]] |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = }} '''Otto Redlich''' (November 4, 1896 – August 14, 1978) was an Austrian [[physical chemist]] and chemical engineer who is best known for his development of equations of state like [[Redlich-Kwong equation]].{{cite journal | last1 = Reif-Acherman | first1 = Simón | title = Otto Redlich: chemist and gentleman from the "old school" | journal = Química Nova | volume = 31 | year = 2008 | doi = 10.1590/S0100-40422008000700053 | issue = 7 | pages = 1901–1908 }}{{cite journal | title = Otto Redlich, 1896–1978: in memory and appreciation | journal = Fluid Phase Equilibria | volume = 12 | pages = 1 | year = 1983 | doi = 10.1016/0378-3812(83)85010-9}} Besides this he had numerous other contributions to science. He won the [[Haitinger Prize]] of the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]] in 1932.{{sfn|Reif-Acherman|2008|p=1902}} ==Biography== Redlich was born 1896 in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]. He went to school in the Döbling district of Vienna. After finishing school in 1915 he joined the Austrian Hungarian Army and served as artillery officer mainly at the Italian front in [[World War I]]. He was wounded and became a prisoner of war in August 1918. He returned to Vienna after the war in 1919. He studied chemistry and received his [[doctorate]] in 1922 for work on the equilibrium of nitric acid, nitrous and nitric oxide. Redlich worked for one year in industry and than joined [[Emil Abel]] at the [[University of Vienna]]. He became lecturer in 1929 and professor in 1937. During this time he developed the [[Teller-Redlich isotopic product rule]].{{cite journal | last = Redlich | first = O. | year = 1935 | title = Eine allgemeine Beziehung zwischen den Schwingungsfrequenzen isotoper Moleküln (nebst Bemerkungen über die Berechnung harmonischer Kraftkonstanten) | journal = [[Zeitschrift für Physikalische Chemie]] B | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 371–382}}{{cite journal | last1 = Schaad | first1 = L.J. | last2 = Bytautas | first2 = Laimutis | last3 = Houk | first3 = K.N. | title = Ab initio test of the usefulness of the Redlich-Teller product rule in computing kinetic isotope effects | journal = Canadian Journal of Chemistry | volume = 77 | pages = 875 | year = 1999 | doi = 10.1139/cjc-77-5-6-875 | issue = 5–6 }}{{cite journal | last1 =Angus | first1 =W. R. | last2 =Bailey | first2 =C. R. | last3 =Hale | first3 =J. B. | last4 =Ingold | first4 =C. K. | last5 =Leckie | first5 =A. H. | last6 =Raisin | first6 =C. G. | last7 =Thompson | first7 =J. W. | last8 =Wilson | first8 =C. L. | title =218. Structure of benzene. Part VIII. Assignment of vibration frequencies of benzene and hexadeuterobenzene | journal =Journal of the Chemical Society (Resumed) | pages =971 | year =1936 | doi =10.1039/JR9360000971}} After the [[Anschluss]] in March 1938, Austria had become a part of [[Nazi Germany]] and with the implementation of the [[Nuremberg Laws]] all government employed Jews lost their jobs, including academics. Like many other scientist Redlich tried to leave the [[Nazi]] governed Austria. With the help of the [[Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced Foreign Scholars]] he was able to emigrate to the United States in December 1938. He gave lectures at several universities and met [[Gilbert N. Lewis]] and [[Linus Pauling]]. [[Harold Urey]] helped him to get a position in [[Washington State College]]. In 1945 he left the College and started to work in industry, at Shell Development Co. in [[Emeryville, California]]. He published his paper on the improvement of the [[Ideal gas law|ideal gas equation]] in 1949, today known as the [[Redlich–Kwong equation of state]].{{cite journal | last1 = Redlich | first1 = Otto | last2 = Kwong | first2 = J. N. S. | title = On the Thermodynamics of Solutions. V. An Equation of State. Fugacities of Gaseous Solutions | journal = Chemical Reviews | volume = 44 | issue = 1 | pages = 233–44 | year = 1949 | pmid = 18125401 | doi = 10.1021/cr60137a013}} In 1962 Redlich retired from Shell and received a position at [[University of California at Berkeley]]. He died in California in 1978. ==Bibliography== * {{cite book|last1=Redlich|first1=Otto|title=Thermodynamics : fundamentals, applications|date=1976|publisher=Elsevier Scientific Pub. Co.|location=Amsterdam|isbn=0444414878|edition=1 ed., 2. impr.}} *{{cite journal|ref=harv|last1=Reif-Acherman|first1=Simón|title=Otto Redlich: chemist and gentleman from the "old school"|journal=Química Nova|date=2008|volume=31|issue=7|doi=10.1590/S0100-40422008000700053|publisher=SciELO|location=São Paulo, Brazil|issn=1678-7064|pages=1901–1908}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Redlich, Otto}} [[Category:Austrian refugees]] [[Category:American people of Austrian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Washington State University faculty]] [[Category:University of Vienna faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:Jewish American scientists]] [[Category:Jewish scientists]] [[Category:Scientists from Vienna]] [[Category:Jewish emigrants from Austria after the Anschluss]] [[Category:Thermodynamicists]] [[Category:Austrian physical chemists]] [[Category:American physical chemists]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:Austrian chemical engineers]] [[Category:American chemical engineers]] [[Category:20th-century American engineers]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} The '''Palmer drought index''', sometimes called the '''Palmer drought severity index''' and often abbreviated '''PDSI''', is a measurement of dryness based on recent [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] and temperature.<ref>[https://www.drought.gov/drought/data-maps-tools/current-conditions Current Palmer Drought Index at National Integrated Drought Information System]</ref> It was developed by [[meteorologist]] Wayne Palmer, who first published his method in the 1965 paper ''Meteorological Drought''<ref name="Palmer1965">Wayne Palmer, "Meteorological Drought". Research paper no.45, U.S. Department of Commerce Weather Bureau, February 1965 (58 pgs). Available online by the [[NOAA]] National Climatic Data Center at http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/temp-and-precip/drought/docs/palmer.pdf</ref> for the Office of Climatology of the [[U.S. Weather Bureau]].
The Palmer Drought Index is based on a [[Supply and demand|supply-and-demand]] model of [[soil moisture]]. Supply is comparatively straightforward to calculate, but demand is more complicated as it depends on many factors, not just temperature and the amount of moisture in the soil but also hard-to-calibrate factors including [[evapotranspiration]] and recharge rates. Palmer tried to overcome these difficulties by developing an algorithm that approximated them based on the most readily available data, precipitation and temperature.
The index has proven most effective in determining long-term drought, a matter of several months, but it is not as good with conditions over a matter of weeks. It uses a 0 as normal, and drought is shown in terms of negative numbers; for example, negative 2 is moderate drought, negative 3 is severe drought, and negative 4 is extreme drought. Palmer's algorithm also is used to describe wet spells, using corresponding positive numbers. Palmer also developed a formula for standardizing drought calculations for each individual location based on the variability of precipitation and temperature at that location. The Palmer index can therefore be applied to any site for which sufficient precipitation and temperature data is available.
Critics have complained that the utility of the Palmer index is weakened by the arbitrary nature of Palmer's algorithms, including the technique used for standardization. The Palmer index's inability to account for snow and frozen ground also is cited as a weakness.<ref>Alley, William: The Palmer Drought Severity Index: Limitations and Assumptions, Journal of Climate and Applied Meteorology, Vol. 23, pp. 1100–09, July 1984</ref>
The Palmer index is widely used operationally, with Palmer maps published weekly by the United States Government's [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]. It also has been used by climatologists to standardize global long-term drought analysis. Global Palmer data sets have been developed based on instrumental records beginning in the 19th century.<ref>Dai, Aiguo et al.: A Global Dataset of Palmer Drought Severity Index for 1870–2002: Relationship with Soil Moisture and Effects of Surface Warming, Journal of Hydrometeorology, Vol. 5, No. 6, pp. 1117–30, December 2004</ref> In addition, [[dendrochronology]] has been used to generate estimated Palmer index values for North America for the past 2000 years, allowing analysis of long term drought trends.<ref>Cook, E.R. et al.: Long-Term Changes in the Western United States, [[Science (journal)|Science]], Vol. 306, No. 5698, pp. 1015–18, November 5, 2004</ref> It has also been used as a means of explaining the late [[Bronze Age collapse]].
In the US, regional Palmer maps are featured on the cable channel [[Weatherscan]].
==See also== * [[Keetch-Byram drought index]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/monitoring_and_data/drought.shtml Drought Monitoring at NOAA's Climate Prediction Center Using the Palmer Drought Index] *[http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/cas/catalog/climind/pdsi.html National Center for Climate and Atmospheric Research, Climate Analysis Section] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120003838/http://drought.mssl.ucl.ac.uk/drought.html UCL Dept. of Space and Climate Physics Global Drought Monitor Using the Palmer Drought Index]

[[File:Preternatural tumours.jpg|thumb|''A Compleat Treatise of Preternatural Tumours'' (1678) by John Brown]] {{Paranormal}} The '''''preternatural''''' or '''''praeternatural''''' is that which appears outside or beside (Latin ''[[:Wikt:preter-|præter]]'') the [[nature|natural]]. It is "suspended between the mundane and the miraculous".Allchin, Douglas, "Monsters & Marvels: How Do We Interpret the "Preternatural"?", ''The American Biology Teacher'', November 2007. p.565. In theology, the term is often used to distinguish marvels or deceptive trickery, often attributed to [[witchcraft]] or [[demon]]s, from the purely [[divinity|divine]] power of the genuinely supernatural to violate the laws of nature. In the [[early modern period]] the term was used by scientists to refer to abnormalities and strange phenomena of various kinds that seemed to depart from the norms of nature. ==Theology== Medieval theologians made a clear distinction between the natural, the preternatural and the supernatural. [[Thomas Aquinas]] argued that the supernatural consists in "God’s unmediated actions"; the natural is "what happens always or most of the time"; and the preternatural is "what happens rarely, but nonetheless by the agency of created beings...Marvels belong, properly speaking, to the realm of the preternatural."Israel Burshatin, "Elena Alias Elewno: Genders, sexualities, and 'race' in the mirror of natural history in sixteenth-century Spain" in Sabrina Petra Ramet, ''Gender Reversals and Gender Cultures: Anthropological and Historical Perspectives'', Routledge, New York, 1996, p.114. Theologians, following Aquinas, argued that only God had the power to disregard the laws of nature that he has created, but that demons could manipulate the laws of nature by a form of trickery, to deceive the unwary into believing they had experienced real miracles. According to historian Lorraine Daston,
Although demons, astral intelligences, and other spirits might manipulate natural causes with superhuman dexterity and thereby work marvels, as mere creatures they could never transcend from the preternatural to the supernatural and work genuine miracles.Lorraine Daston, "Marvelous Facts and Miraculous Evidence in Early Modern Europe", Peter G. Platt, ''Wonders, Marvels, and Monsters in Early Modern Culture'', University of Delaware Press, Newark, 1999, pp. 76–105.
By the 16th century, the term "preternatural" was increasingly used to refer to demonic activity comparable to the use of magic by human adepts: The Devil, "being a natural Magician … may perform many acts in ways above our knowledge, though not transcending our natural power." According to the philosophy of the time, preternatural phenomena were not contrary to divine law, but used hidden, or [[occult]] powers that violated the ''normal'' pattern of natural phenomena. ==Science== With the emergence of early modern science, the concept of the preternatural increasingly came to be used to refer to strange or abnormal phenomena that seemed to violate the normal working of nature, but which were not associated with magic and witchcraft. This was a development of the idea that preternatural phenomena were fake miracles. As Daston puts it, "To simplify the historical sequence somewhat: first, preternatural phenomena were demonized and thereby incidentally naturalized; then the demons were deleted, leaving only the natural causes." The use of the term was especially common in medicine, for example in John Brown's ''A Compleat Treatise of Preternatural Tumours'' (1678), or [[William Smellie (obstetrician)|William Smellie]]'s ''A Collection of Preternatural Cases and Observations in Midwifery'' (1754).Samuel J. Rogal, ''Medicine in Great Britain from the Restoration to the Nineteenth Century, 1660–1800: An Annotated Bibliography'', Greenwood Press, New York, 1992, p.203. In the 19th century the term was appropriated in anthropology to refer to folk beliefs about fairies, trolls and other such creatures which were not thought of as demonic, but which were perceived to affect the natural world in unpredictable ways. According to [[Thorstein Veblen]], such preternatural agents were often thought of as forces somewhere between supernatural beings and material processes. "The preternatural agency is not necessarily conceived to be a personal agent in the full sense, but it is an agency which partakes of the attributes of personality to the extent of somewhat arbitrarily influencing the outcome of any enterprise, and especially of any contest."Veblen, T., ''The Theory of the Leisure Class: An Economic Study of Institutions'', Macmillan, New York, 1915, p.280 The linguistic association between individual agents and unexplained or unfortunate circumstances remains. Many people attribute occurrences that are known to be material processes, such as "gremlins in the engine", a "ghost in the machine", or [[pathetic fallacy|attributing motives to objects]]: "the clouds are threatening". The anthropomorphism in our daily life is a combination of the above cultural stems, as well as the manifestation of our pattern-projecting minds.{{or|date=June 2015}} ==Scholarship== In 2011, Penn State Press began publishing a learned journal entitled ''Preternature: Critical and Historical Studies on the Preternatural''. Edited by Kirsten Uszkalo and Richard Raiswell, the journal is dedicated to publishing articles, reviews and short editions of original texts that deal with conceptions and perceptions of the preternatural in any culture and in any historical period. The journal covers "magics, witchcraft, spiritualism, occultism, prophecy, monstrophy, demonology, and folklore."{{cite web |url=http://www.psupress.org/journals/jnls_Preternature.html |title=''Preternature: Critical and Historical Studies on the Preternatural'' |publisher=Penn State University Press |access-date=28 December 2017}} ==See also== * [[Paranormal]] * [[Supernatural]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|preternatural}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060819143823/http://www.fortea.us/english/teologicos/diferencias.htm "What is the difference between natural, preternatural and supernatural?"] ''Possession and Exorcism'', J.A. Fortea [[Category:Nature]] [[Category:Epistemology of science]]

{{Chembox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 429136924 | ImageFile = | ImageFile2 = Magnesium-diboride-3D-balls.png | IUPACName = Rhenium diboride |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|??}} | CASNo = 12355-99-6 | PubChem = 57418167 | SMILES = B#[Re]#B | EC_number = 234-959-3 | InChI = InChI=1S/2B.Re | InChIKey = OLXPHXSOQYDZNT-UHFFFAOYSA-N }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = ReB<sub>2</sub> | MolarMass = 207.83 g/mol | Appearance = black powder | Density = 12.7 g/cm<sup>3</sup> | MeltingPtC = 2400 | MeltingPt_ref = <ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/BF00775787|title=Forward slip in the rolling of strip from metal powders|year=1968|last1=Gaidar'|first1=L. M.|last2=Zhilkin|first2=V. Z.|journal=Soviet Powder Metallurgy and Metal Ceramics|volume=7|issue=4|page=258}}</ref> | BoilingPt = | Solubility = none }} |Section3={{Chembox Structure | CrystalStruct = [[Hexagonal]], Space group P6<sub>3</sub>/mmc. | Coordination = }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = | GHSPictograms = {{GHS07}}<ref name=sds>{{cite web|title = Rhenium Diboride|url = https://www.americanelements.com/rhenium-diboride-12355-99-6|website = [[American Elements]]|accessdate = 2018-08-02}}</ref> | GHSSignalWord = Warning<ref name=sds /> | HPhrases = {{H-phrases|315|319|335}}<ref name=sds /> | PPhrases = {{P-phrases|261|280|305+351+338|304+340|405|501}}<ref name=sds /> }} }}
'''Rhenium diboride''' (ReB<sub>2</sub>) is a synthetic [[superhard material]]. It was first synthesized in 1962{{hsp}}<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1107/S0365110X62000298|title=The crystal structure of rhenium diboride|year=1962|last1=La Placa|first1=S. J.|last2=Post|first2=B.|journal=Acta Crystallographica|volume=15|issue=2|pages=97}}</ref> and re-emerged recently due to hopes of achieving high hardness comparable to that of [[diamond]].<ref name="Chung">{{cite journal | last = Chung | first = Hsiu-Ying | date = April 20, 2007 | title = Synthesis of Ultra-Incompressible Superhard Rhenium Diboride at Ambient Pressure | journal = Science | volume = 316 | issue = 5823 | pages = 436–9 | doi = 10.1126/science.1139322 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/316/5823/436 | pmid = 17446399 | display-authors = 1 | last2 = Weinberger | first2 = M. B. | last3 = Levine | first3 = J. B. | last4 = Kavner | first4 = A. | last5 = Yang | first5 = J.-M. | last6 = Tolbert | first6 = S. H. | last7 = Kaner | first7 = R. B. | last8 = Kaner | first8 = RB| bibcode = 2007Sci...316..436C }}</ref> The reported ultrahigh hardness has been questioned,<ref name=comment/> although this is a matter of definition as in the initial test rhenium diboride was able to scratch diamond.<ref name="Chung"/>
The production method of this material does not involve high pressures as with other hard synthetic materials, such as [[cubic boron nitride]], which makes production cheap. However, rhenium itself is an expensive metal.
The compound is formed from a mixture of [[rhenium]], noted for its resistance to high pressure, and [[boron]], which forms short, strong [[covalent bond]]s with rhenium.
== Synthesis == [[File:Rhenium_Diboride.jpg|thumb|left|Rhenium diboride, ReB<sub>2</sub>]]
ReB<sub>2</sub> can be synthesized by at least three different methods at standard atmospheric pressure: solid-state [[metathesis reaction (chemistry)|metathesis]], melting in an [[electric arc]], and direct heating of the elements.<ref name="Chung" />
In the metathesis reaction, [[rhenium trichloride]] and [[magnesium diboride]] are mixed and heated in an inert atmosphere and the [[magnesium chloride]] byproduct is washed away. Excess boron is needed to prevent formation of other phases such as Re<sub>7</sub>B<sub>3</sub> and Re<sub>3</sub>B.
In the arc-melting method, rhenium and boron powders are mixed and a large electric current is passed through the mixture, also in an inert atmosphere.
In the direct reaction method, the rhenium-boron mixture is sealed in a vacuum and held at a high temperature over a longer period (1000 °C for five days).
At least the last two methods are capable of producing pure ReB<sub>2</sub> without any other phases, as confirmed by [[X-ray crystallography]].
== Properties == The hardness of ReB<sub>2</sub> exhibits considerable [[anisotropy]] because of its hexagonal layered structure (see structure model), being greatest along the ''c'' axis. In contrast to the [[Mohs hardness scale|scratch hardness test]], its [[Vickers hardness scale|indentation hardness]] (H<sub>V</sub> ~ 22 GPa)<ref name=comment>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/adma.200801471|title=Is Rhenium Diboride a Superhard Material?|year=2008|last1=Qin|first1=Jiaqian|last2=He|first2=Duanwei|last3=Wang|first3=Jianghua|last4=Fang|first4=Leiming|last5=Lei|first5=Li|last6=Li|first6=Yongjun|last7=Hu|first7=Juan|last8=Kou|first8=Zili|last9=Bi|first9=Yan|journal=Advanced Materials|volume=20|issue=24|pages=4780}}</ref> is much lower than that of diamond and is comparable to that of [[tungsten carbide]], [[silicon carbide]], [[titanium diboride]] or [[zirconium diboride]].<ref name=comment />
ReB<sub>2</sub> slowly reacts with water, converting into a hydroxide.
Two factors contribute to the high hardness of ReB<sub>2</sub>: a high density of [[valence electron]]s, and an abundance of short [[covalent bond]]s.<ref name="Chung"/><ref>{{cite journal | title = Electronic, dynamical, and thermal properties of ultra-incompressible superhard rhenium diboride: A combined first-principles and neutron scattering study |author1=W. Zhou |author2=H. Wu |author3=T. Yildirim |last-author-amp=yes | url = http://link.aps.org/abstract/PRB/v76/e184113 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.76.184113 | journal = Phys. Rev. B | volume = 76 | issue = 18 | pages = 184113–184119 | year =2007|arxiv=0708.3694 |bibcode=2007PhRvB..76r4113Z }}</ref> Rhenium has one of the highest valence electron densities of any transition metal (476 electrons/nm<sup>3</sup>, compare to 572 electrons/nm<sup>3</sup> for [[osmium]] and 705 electrons/nm<sup>3</sup> for diamond<ref name="Cumberland">{{cite journal | last = Cumberland | first = Robert W. | date = April 27, 2005 | title = Osmium Diboride, An Ultra-Incompressible, Hard Material | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 127 | issue = 20 | pages = 7264–5 | doi = 10.1021/ja043806y | url = http://pubs.acs.org/cgi-bin/abstract.cgi/jacsat/2005/127/i20/abs/ja043806y.html | pmid = 15898746 | display-authors = 1 | last2 = Weinberger | first2 = Michelle B. | last3 = Gilman | first3 = John J. | last4 = Clark | first4 = Simon M. | last5 = Tolbert | first5 = Sarah H. | last6 = Kaner | first6 = Richard B.}}</ref>). The addition of boron requires only a 5% expansion of the rhenium lattice, because the small boron atoms fill the existing spaces between the rhenium atoms. Furthermore, the [[electronegativity|electronegativities]] of rhenium and boron are close enough (1.9 and 2.04 on the [[Electronegativity#Pauling electronegativity|Pauling scale]]) that they form covalent bonds in which the electrons are shared almost equally.
==See also== * [[Network covalent bonding]] * [[Superhard material]]
